(2)
It is unlawful for any person to refuse or fail to pay fees or fines associated with the violations of this section.
All fines and fees due to the city must be paid by the person to whom the water/utility bill is registered with the
city (i.e. the property owner or the trash pickup user where applicable). The ultimate responsibility for payment
will lie with the property owner.
(3)
Fines and fees not paid within thirty (30) days of the billing date will be assessed a ten (10) percent penalty on
the outstanding balance. All fines and fees not paid after ninety (90) days will be turned over to a collection
agency selected by the city for collection. The violator will be responsible for all costs associated with this
action up to and including legal fees.
(4)
This section shall be enforced by the code enforcement division of the city through the issuance of garbage
violation notices which shall be forwarded to the finance department of the city for tracking and billing. The
fines assessed for each violation as indicated in the schedule above will be billed on the water/utility bill.
(b)
Receptacles referred to in section 10-3 shall be enclosed by a solid fence on three (3) sides, which fence shall be
no less than four (4) feet high and which shall, in any event be as high as the receptacle enclosed therein, if such
receptacle is greater than four (4) feet high. There shall be a curb of approximately six (6) inches in height and
sufficient to prevent the garbage receptacle contained in the enclosed area from rolling across said curb across
the open side of the enclosed area.
(c)
No building permit shall be issued by the building department until the building official has issued a permit for
the construction and location of containers for the storage and collection of garbage and trash. Said permit shall
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
349/653
ensure the compliance with the provisions of this chapter relating to location of receptacle for storage and
collection of garbage and trash, including, but not limited to, bulk containers.
(d)
The fee for the insurance of such permit shall be in the amount of three dollars ($3.00).
(e)
This section shall not be applicable to garbage receptacles maintained in the interior of buildings.
(Ord. No. 229, § 1, 6-26-72; Ord. No. 379, §§ 1—4, 7-29-74; Ord. No. 06O-04-126, § 1, 5-8-06)
Sec. 10-4.1. - Appeals.
Anyone who is issued a garbage violation notice for a garbage container violation may appeal that notice in the
following manner:
(a)
Written notice of the appeal must be filed with the chief code enforcement officer within ten (10) days following
the issuance of the garbage violation notice. The appeal shall state the name and address of the appellant, the
date of the violation, and the reason why, in the opinion of the appellant, the appealed action should be reversed.
(b)
The appeal will be heard by the chief code enforcement officer or his/her designee within fifteen (15) days
following the date of receipt of appeal by the chief code enforcement officer.
(c)
The chief code enforcement officer, or his/her designee, shall issue a written decision of his/her determination.
(d)
In the event that the decision is adverse to the appellant, the appellant may, within thirty (30) days of the
issuance of the written decision file a written subsequent appeal with the city manager. The city manager or
his/her designee shall consider the written appeal and provide a determination within fifteen (15) days following
the date of receipt of subsequent appeal by the city manager. The decision of the city manager shall be deemed
final and the exhaustion of the appellant's administrative remedies.
(e)
While the appellate process is pending, no adverse action shall be taken against the appellant if the appellant
shall have posted with the city, at the time that the written notice of appeal is filed, a bond equal to the amount of
the fine due as claimed by the city.
(Ord. No. 06O-04-126, § 2, 5-8-06)
Sec. 10-5. - Same—Placement by commercial establishments and public buildings.
Commercial establishments and public buildings shall place all receptacles for collection at one single point
easily accessible and in such a manner and location as to enable collection vehicles to get within ten (10) feet of
said receptacles measured from the edges of street or serviceable alley right-of-way except as otherwise
permitted by the city.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
350/653
(Ord. No. 199, § 3, 9-7-71)
Sec. 10-6. - Duty to obtain collection service.
(a)
Each occupied dwelling unit and each business or commercial establishment must obtain adequate garbage and
trash collection service from that company or organization franchised by the city to provide such garbage and
trash collection within the city limits.
(b)
Each occupied residential unit located in a building containing four (4) or less residential units shall contract and
make adequate arrangements for adequate garbage and trash collection with that company or organization
franchised to provide such service in the city, and each such service in the city shall be billed as an individual
home and each such dwelling unit in buildings of four (4) or less shall be deemed an individual account and
shall be billed quarterly in advance in accordance with the rate set for individual single-family residences
located within the city by city ordinance.
(c)
Garbage and trash collection service shall be obtained by the owner of the building or buildings of each dwelling
unit, as applicable, and shall not be obtained by tenants thereof. However, owners of units which are in
condominiums whose condominium association obtains and pays for the garbage and trash collection service
shall be exempt from this requirement. The association may obtain and pay for the trash collection service.
(d)
Any person, firm, corporation or organization found guilty of violation of this section shall be fined and/or
imprisoned not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or thirty (30) days or both.
(Ord. No. 137, § 1, 8-31-70; Ord. No. 75-439, §§ 1—3, 9-30-75; Ord. No. 91-207, § 1, 1-13-92; Ord. No. 93-
169, § 2, 3, 10-12-93)
Sec. 10-7. - Placing, sweeping, scattering, littering, or dumping prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for any person to place, sweep, scatter, litter, dump or cause to be placed, swept, scattered,
littered, or dumped, any garbage, trash, or litter in or upon any street, sidewalk, alley, canal, watercourse, vacant
lot, city park or city property of any kind or upon any improved property, within the limits of the city.
Shopping carts and unauthorized signs shall be considered litter for purposes of this section. The city manager
may negotiate contracts with shopping cart owners for the return of shopping carts by city personnel. Such
contracts, if negotiated and enforced, would take priority over enforcement of this section with respect to
shopping carts.
F.S. ch. 403, entitled "Environmental Control, Part I, Pollution Control," as existing or as may be amended from
time to time, is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference into this Code for enforcement purposes of this
section.
(Ord. No. 8, § 2, 12-28-59; Ord. No. 91-102, § 1, 1-28-91; Ord. No. 00O-2-13, § 1, 2-28-00)
Sec. 10-8. - Disposal to be in accordance with chapter.
It shall be unlawful for any person to bury, burn or dispose of any trash, rubbish, garbage, offal, dead animals, or
other waste matter in the city except in the manner provided by this chapter.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
351/653
(Ord. No. 8, § 3, 12-28-59)
Sec. 10-9. - Miscellaneous requirements for wrapping, sorting.
All garbage or debris which might contain any moisture shall first be wrapped in paper before being placed in
the garbage receptacle. Bottles and cans shall be deposited in garbage receptacles for that purpose, other than
receptacles used for the disposition of other garbage.
(Ord. No. 8, § 5, 12-28-59)
Sec. 10-10. - Disposals permitted.
The provisions of this chapter relating to the disposition of garbage shall not prohibit the use of disposals
connected to the sanitary sewer system.
(Ord. No. 8, § 6, 12-28-59)
Sec. 10-11. - Incinerators prohibited.
The operation of any incinerator within the limits of the city is hereby prohibited.
(Ord. No. 8, § 7, 12-28-59)
Sec. 10-12. - Violation to constitute public nuisance.
The operation of any incinerator or the disposal of trash, rubbish, garbage, dead animals, offal or other waste
matter in the city in violation of the provision of this chapter is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and is
prohibited.
(Ord. No. 8, § 8, 12-28-59)
Sec. 10-13. - Multifamily dwellings, garbage and trash collection requirements.
(a)
This section does not pertain to multifamily dwellings which utilize bulk containers.
(b)
There shall be a separate garbage and trash receptacle for each dwelling unit in each multifamily dwelling.
(c)
Each garbage and trash receptacle shall be placed in the swale area at the address where the dwelling is located,
and shall be placed only on dates and times which are specified for garbage and trash collection at that address.
(d)
Each garbage and trash receptacle shall be clearly and legibly marked with the street address where the dwelling
unit is located and with the dwelling unit number, if applicable. Each letter or number shall be at least three (3)
inches high and shall be in a color contrasting with the color of the garbage and trash receptacle. Only one (1)
color shall be utilized for all letters and numbers.
(e)
The price for the garbage and trash receptacle, to be paid by the customer, shall be fifty-five dollars ($55.00) if
paid before November 1, 1995.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
352/653
(f)
If the garbage and trash receptacle is not paid for by the customer prior to November 1, 1995, the price shall then
be sixty-six dollars ($66.00), and the customer shall then be subject to the terms of section 21-46(s) of the Code.
(g)
Any person, firm, corporation or organization found guilty of violation of this section shall be fined and/or
imprisoned not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or thirty (30) days, or both.
(Ord. No. 93-169, § 1, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 95-149, § 1, 9-11-95)
Sec. 10-14. - Reserved.
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 92-133, § 2, adopted April 27, 1992, repealed § 10-14 in its entirety. Formerly, §
10-14 pertained to newspaper recycling fees and derived from Ord. No. 89-202, § 1, adopted Dec. 11, 1989.
Similar provisions are located in § 10-22.
Sec. 10-15. - Unsanitary and/or unsightly conditions on private property.
(a)
Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively
ascribed to them:
Garbage: All kitchen and table refuse, all general combustible waste, pasteboard boxes, accumulation of animal
or vegetable matter which attends to the preparation, use, cooking, processing, handling or storage of meats,
fish, fowl, fruits, vegetables and other matter which is subject to decomposition, decay, putrefaction or the
generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors which, during or after decay, may serve as breeding places or
breeding material for flies, insects or animals.
Trash: Every waste, accumulation or deposit of paper, sweepings, dust, rags, bottles, cans and other matter of
any substance or kind including, but not necessarily limited to, substantive compositions of paper, wood, metal,
brick, glass and matters of similar import and composition and specifically including such matters as
refrigerators and stoves, paper cups, bottlecaps, beverage cans and all types of paper and construction debris.
Unsecured property: Vacant or unoccupied building(s) or structure(s) containing broken windows, doors,
doorways or any other entranceway.
Vegetation: All natural growth upon a lot or parcel of ground, including grass, weeds, trees, vines, bushes,
underbrush and the waste material arising therefrom.
Yard trash: Every waste accumulation of lawn, grass or shrubbery cutting or clippings and dry-leaf rakings,
rocks, branches, palm fronds, tree branches, parts of trees, bushes or shrubs, green-leaf cuttings, coconuts, fruit
or other matter usually created as refuse in the care of trees or large bushes.
(b)
Declaration of legislative intent. The city commission finds and determines that the rapid, continuous growth
and development of this city, in addition to the increase in the number of foreclosed and abandoned properties,
requires the reasonable and effective control and regulation of excessive growth and accumulation of weeds,
rubbish, trash and dead trees, standing or fallen, unkempt pools, or dilapidated fences and walls, to the extent
and in such manner as to prevent infestation by rodents and other wild animals, the breeding of mosquitoes and
vermin, the threat to or endangering of the public health, safety, or welfare, or circumstances which may
reasonably cause disease, or the adverse effect and the impairing of the economic welfare of adjacent property.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
353/653
(c)
Excessive undergrowth, accumulation of junk, trash, declared public nuisance; prohibited. No person owning or
having possession of any land shall permit the existence of excessive accumulation of untended growth of grass,
weeds, vegetation, rubbish, trash and dead trees, standing or fallen, upon any lot, tract or parcel of land,
improved or unimproved, within the city to the extent and in the manner that such lot, tract or parcel of land is or
may reasonably become infested or inhabited by rodents, vermin or wild animals, or may furnish a breeding
place for mosquitoes, or threatens or endangers the public health, safety or welfare or may reasonably cause
disease or adversely affects and impairs the economic welfare of adjacent property, is hereby prohibited and
declared to be a public nuisance.
(d)
Standing water, pools, swamp creating public hazard or nuisance; prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person
to have, keep, maintain, cause or permit within the city limits any collection of standing water, pool, or any
swamp, marsh or overflowed lands which create a public hazard or nuisance as a breeding place for mosquitoes,
pests, rats, snakes and other vermin, reptiles or insects, or which create a safety hazard such that the water is
stagnant, or has any accumulation of garbage or solid waste, or where the water clarity is not sufficient so that
the deepest point is not clearly visible from the pool or structure's edge.
(e)
Accumulation of trash and rubbish prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, sweep or scatter or
cause to be placed, swept or scattered any trash, rubbish, paper, fruit peelings, debris, refuse or filth upon any
street, lot, tract, parcel of land, sidewalk, parkway or bank of any river, stream or waterway, alley or any vacant
lot or upon any improved property, regardless of ownership and to dump or deposit in any stream, watercourse
or pool within the limits of the city any trash, debris, refuse, paper, oil, vegetable and mineral matter or other
substance that will tend to pollute the waters of such stream, watercourse or pool.
(f)
Unsecured vacant building(s) or structure(s); dilapidated fences, walls, parking lots and potholes prohibited .
Any and all vacant or unoccupied building(s) or structure(s) which are unsecured are the responsibility of the
property owner to secure said unoccupied or vacant building(s) or structure(s). Should the property owner fail to
do so, code enforcement is hereby authorized to secure any and all unsecured property, building(s) or
structure(s) as defined in subsection (a) above, which is deemed a health or safety hazard without prior notice to
the property owner. After causing the condition to be remedied, the director of the code enforcement division
shall certify to the finance department the expense whereupon such expense shall be billed to the property owner
and shall become payable in thirty (30) [days] after which a lien shall be placed on the property in accordance
with subsection (i)(2) herein. Dilapidated accessory uses or structures on any property, including but not limited
to, fences and walls, parking lots and potholes, which may cause a safety hazard, in addition to being unsightly,
shall be prohibited and declared to be a public nuisance.
(g)
Notice of prohibited conditions. If the code enforcement division director finds and determines that a public
nuisance as described and declared in this section exists, he/she shall have a code enforcement officer notify the
record owner of the offending property in writing and demand that such owner cause the condition to be
remedied. The notice shall be given either: (i) by hand-delivery of the notice at the violator's property with a
person residing at the property above fifteen (15) years of age and informing such person of the contents of the
notice; or (ii) if hand-delivery could not be accomplished, then via certified mail and regular mail addressed to
the owner or owners of the property described as their names and addresses are shown upon the county tax
records and at any other mailing address provided to the city by owner, and such mailed notice shall be deemed
complete and sufficient when so addressed and deposited in the United States mail with proper postage prepaid
as well as physically posted on the property. The notice shall be in substantially the following form:
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
354/653
NOTICE OF PUBLIC NUISANCE
Name of owner _____
Address of owner _____
Our records indicate that you are the owner(s) of the following property in Lauderhill, Florida:
(Describe property)
After inspection of this property, I have found and determined that a public nuisance exists thereon so as to
constitute a violation of Section 10-15 of the Lauderhill City Code in that:
(Describe here the condition which places the property in violation)
You are hereby notified that unless the condition above-described is remedied so as to make it nonviolative of
Section 10-15 of the Lauderhill City Code within ten (10) days from the date hereof, the City of Lauderhill will
proceed to remedy this condition; and the cost of the work, including any and all actual expenses, will be
imposed as a lien on the property if not otherwise paid within thirty (30) days after receipt of billing. Within five
(5) days of the mailing of this notice, you have the right to make written request to the code enforcement
division director for a hearing before the code enforcement board to show that the condition alleged in this
notice does not exist or that such condition does not constitute a public nuisance.
City of Lauderhill
By _____
Code Enforcement Officer
Phone _____
Date of Notice of Violation
(h)
Hearing. Within five (5) days after the mailing of the notice specified in subsection (g) to the property owner, the
owner of the property may make written request to the code enforcement division director for a hearing to show
that the condition alleged in the notice does not exist or that such condition does not constitute a public nuisance.
At the hearing, the city and the property owner may introduce such evidence as is deemed necessary. The code
enforcement board shall hold hearings as promptly as practicable within thirty (30) calendar days of the filing of
the appeal at a regularly scheduled code enforcement board meeting to be held at city hall.
(i)
Condition may be remedied by city; costs of remedy to constitute lien on property.
(1)
If, within ten (10) days after mailing of the notice required by subsection (g), no hearing has been requested and
the condition described in the notice has not been remedied, the code enforcement division director is authorized
to cause the condition to be remedied by the city or its agents at the expense of the property owner. If a hearing
has been held and has concluded adversely to the property owner, and the property owner has failed to remedy
the condition, the code enforcement division director shall cause the condition to be remedied by the city or its
agents at the expense of the property owner.
(2)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
355/653
After causing the condition to be remedied, the director of the code enforcement division shall certify to the
finance department the expense incurred in remedying the condition and shall include a copy of the notice above
described and such expense shall be billed to the property owner and shall become payable within thirty (30)
days after which a lien and charge will be made upon the property, which lien shall be payable with interest at
the then current legal rate of interest per annum, from the date of such certification until paid. Such expenses
shall be determined by the director of the finance department and shall include any and all additional costs and
expenses incurred by the city, including, but not limited to, the direct costs of inspection and of monitoring the
property for repeat violations for three (3) months following the initial violation at the rate of one (1) hour per
month, billing, recording of the liens, satisfactions of said liens, mailing costs, all actual out-of-pocket expenses
and all other costs that may be incurred in connection with remedying the condition. The invoice sent to the
property owner shall contain a statement advising that a failure to pay the amount invoiced will result in the
imposition of a non-ad valorem assessment on their next available annual tax bill; shall advise that the property
is then subject to the sale of a tax certificate bearing interest by law at a rate as high as eighteen (18) percent per
annum if the non-ad valorem assessment is not paid as part of the tax bill on the subject property; and shall
further advise of the potential for the property to be sold and conveyed via tax deed if the tax certificate is not
redeemed by payment of the non-ad valorem assessment in full, plus interest, as required by Florida law. If the
owner fails or refuses to pay the full amount due on the invoice by September 30, then the total of any and all
related costs incurred in connection with remedying the conditions, including also any administrative fees
charged by the Broward County Property Appraiser or Broward County Tax Collector for placement on the
annual tax bill, may be assessed against the property on the next available annual tax bill. This assessment shall
constitute a lien upon the tax parcels so assessed equal in rank and dignity with the liens of all state, county,
district or municipal taxes and non-ad valorem assessments. Except as otherwise provided by law, such lien shall
be superior in dignity to all other liens, titles, and claims until paid. The lien for the nuisance abatement
assessment shall be deemed perfected upon adoption by the city commission of its annual adoption of its non-ad
valorem assessment roll resolution and shall attach to the property included on the assessment roll as of the prior
January 1, the lien date for ad valorem taxes, consistent with F.S. § 197.3632.
(3)
Such lien shall be enforceable in the same manner as a mortgage and may be satisfied at any time by payment
thereof, including accrued interest. Notice of such lien certified by the city clerk may be filed in the office of the
clerk of the circuit court and recorded among the public records of Broward County, Florida. The lien shall
become void twenty (20) years after the date of the execution of the notice of lien. Said lien, together with all
penalties imposed thereon, shall constitute, and are hereby imposed as, special assessment liens against the real
property aforesaid, and until fully paid and discharged, or barred by law, shall remain liens equal in rank and
dignity with the lien of city and county ad valorem taxes and superior in rank and dignity to all other liens,
encumbrances, titles and claims in, to or against the real property involved. The payment of all costs of
collection, including reasonable attorney's fees, penalties, and lien amounts is required before said lien shall be
discharged or satisfied. Said liens shall accrue interest at the then-current legal rate of interest per annum.
(4)
If it is determined by the director of the public works department or the code enforcement division that an
immediate threat or clear and present danger exists as to the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city,
the public works department and the code enforcement division is hereby authorized to provide for the
immediate removal and abatement of any such immediate threat or danger. The property owner shall be notified
as quickly as possible and shall be afforded a hearing, if requested pursuant to subsection (h) of this section.

Sec. 10-16. - Chipping services.
The city shall provide chipping services to single-family residential units located within the city under the
following terms and conditions:
(1)
Materials to be chipped by the city shall be determined from time to time by the city.
(2)
All materials to be chipped by the city shall be placed adjacent to the street at times to be designated by the city.
(3)
The fee to be charged by the city to the consumer shall be charged to the consumer when the city responds to a
chipping services request by the consumer. It shall be the obligation of the consumer to assure that the permitted
materials are at the curbside at the time designated for chipping. The department of environmental and
engineering services shall set the schedule for service.
(4)
The fee to be paid by the consumer shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per hour. The minimum charge shall be
seventy-five dollars ($75.00). Service shall begin upon arrival of the city vehicle at the property site. All service
shall be billed to the consumer as an additional charge on the utility bills, section 21-46 of the Code.
(5)
[Activities included and excluded.]
a.
The service shall include the following activities:
1.
Chipping tree limbs of up to eight (8) inches in diameter;
2.
At the consumer's request, any wood chips created by the city's chipping services may be left by the city at the
consumer's property for use by the property owner; and
3.
Raking the leaves left from tree branches into a pile on the swale.
b.
The service shall not include:
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
358/653
1.
Removal of any bagged or bundled yard waste;
2.
Chipping any tree limbs over eight (8) inches in diameter; or
3.
Removal of any waste for any species of palm tree, or any other type of municipal garbage.
(6)
Chipping services shall be available only to consumers in single-family residential units who maintain an active
water account with the city.
(Ord. No. 98O-8-137, § 1, 9-14-98)
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 98O-8-137, adopted Sept. 14, 1998, amended § 10-16 to read as herein
set out. Prior to such amendment, § 10-16 pertained to removal of tree limbs and other yard waste by the city
and derived from Ord. No. 91-157, § 1, adopted Sept. 11, 1991; Ord. No. 92-139, § 1, adopted May 26, 1992;
and Ord. No. 92-152, § 1, adopted June 8, 1992.

ARTICLE II. - RECYCLABLE WASTE
Sec. 10-20. - Recycling procedure.
(a)
Single-family (any dwelling unit or units that receive curbside garbage pick-up service shall be defined as
single-family for purposes of this article only).
(1)
Newspapers (a periodical, usually daily or weekly, printed on newsprint) shall be segregated from all other waste
material. The newspapers shall be securely bundled with string or twine or placed in a paper grocery bag or like
disposable container and placed out for collection on scheduled days established by the city along with, but
separate from, all other refuse at curbside or next to the refuse container used by such solid waste customers.
Newspapers shall not be placed in plastic bags or mixed with magazines, telephone directories, cardboard, shiny
advertising print or inserts. Adequate precaution shall be made to prevent newspapers from being scattered by
the elements.
(2)
Clear glass and aluminum cans shall be segregated from all other waste materials and shall be placed in a
container which will be provided for this service by the waste hauler who is retained by the city to remove
recyclable waste. The container shall be placed at curbside for collection on scheduled days established by the
city, next to the refuse container used by the customer for removal of all other solid waste materials.
(b)
Multi-family (any group of dwelling units that are serviced by bulk containers).
(1)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
359/653
Newspapers, as defined in section 10-20 (a)(1), shall be placed in a separate container designated for that
purpose, which newspaper container shall be located near the bulk container. The newspapers shall be securely
bundled with string or twine or placed in a paper garbage bag or like disposable container.
(2)
Aluminum cans shall be placed in a container designated for that purpose, which shall be separate from the
newspaper container and which shall be located near the bulk container.
(c)
The recyclable waste services as set forth in this section shall not be optional, but shall be required of all
residents to the extent as set forth herein.
(Ord. No. 92-128, § 1, 4-13-92)
Sec. 10-21. - Unauthorized collection; penalties.
It shall be a violation of this section for any person, firm or corporation not authorized by the city, in writing, to
collect or remove any newspaper, aluminum can or clear glass container which has been specifically placed for
collection in the recycling program. Violations shall be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars
($500.00) or a term of imprisonment in the county jail not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both. Each individual
unauthorized removal shall be considered a separate violation.
(Ord. No. 92-128, § 1, 4-13-92)
Sec. 10-22. - Fees.
(a)
Collection; application. Each single-family unit within the city, as defined in section 10-20 of this Code shall be
charged a fee of three dollars and ten cents ($3.10) per month as a fee for the collection of recyclable waste.
Each multifamily unit, as defined in section 10-20 of this Code shall be charged a fee of one dollar and sixty-one
cents ($1.61) per month as a fee for the collection of recyclable waste. The fee shall be collected concurrent with
and under the same procedures as the city's water and sewer service fees, sections 21-45 and 21-46 of this Code.
Application for service under section 21-46 shall constitute application for service under this section. All current
applications under section 21-46 which are in effect as of April 27, 1992, shall be applications for this service.
The fee as enacted hereunder shall be effective August 1, 2014.
(b)
Increase/decrease.
(1)
Periodically, the fee as enacted herein may be increased or decreased pursuant to the formula as set forth in
section 12 and 13 of the Residential curbside Recycling Agreement, as adopted by Resolution 89-287. A copy of
Resolution 89-287 and the Residential Recycling Agreement shall be retained in the clerk's office for public
inspection at all times while this section is in effect.
(2)
The following increased or new fees are approved:
a.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
360/653
Newspapers; clear glass; aluminum; plastics one, two and three; brown and green glass; and steel cans, singlefamily
residential units: Three dollars and ten cents ($3.10) per unit per month.
b.
Newspapers; clear glass; aluminum; plastics one, two and three; brown and green glass; and steel cans,
multifamily residential units: One dollar and sixty-one cents ($1.61) per unit per month.
(Ord. No. 92-133, § 1, 4-27-92; Ord. No. 93-180, § 3, 11-8-93; Ord. No. 13O-01-100, § 1, 1-28-2013; Ord. No.
14O-04-118, § 1, 5-12-2014)

ARTICLE III. - ABANDONED REAL PROPERTY REGISTRATION, MAINTENANCE AND
FORECLOSURE REPORTING
Sec. 10-30. - Title.
This article may be cited as the "Abandoned Real Property Registration, Maintenance, and Foreclosure
Reporting Ordinance."
(Ord. No. 12O-04-109, § 1, 4-30-2012)
Sec. 10-31. - Purpose and intent.
(a)
It is the purpose and intent of the city to establish a process to address the increasing amount of abandoned real
property located within the city. Further, it is the city's intent to specifically establish an abandoned property
registration and maintenance program as a mechanism to protect residential and commercial neighborhoods
from being blighted through the lack of maintenance and security of abandoned properties.
(b)
The provisions and procedures contained in this article shall be considered cumulative and in addition to and
supplemental to any other remedies now existing or subsequently available to the city including, but not
necessarily limited to, those set forth in the City's Code, Broward County Code, the Florida Building Code, and
State and Federal Statutes.
(Ord. No. 12O-04-109, § 1, 4-30-2012)
Sec. 10-32. - Definitions.
For the purpose of this article, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the following meanings, except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Abandoned property means any real property that is vacant of lawful occupants or not properly maintained and
has had a lis pendens filed against it by the lender holding a mortgage on the property, is subject to an ongoing
foreclosure action, under a notice of mortgagee's sale by the lender or a pending tax assessors lien sale and/or
properties that have been the subject of a foreclosure sale where the title was retained by the beneficiary of a
mortgage involved in the foreclosure and any properties transferred under a deed in lieu of foreclosure or sale.
The designation of a property as "abandoned" shall remain in place until such time as the property is sold or
transferred to a new owner or the foreclosure action has been dismissed.
Enforcement officer means any law enforcement officer, building official, code enforcement officer, fire
inspector, or building inspector employed by the city, or other city employee or city agent authorized by the city
manager or by City Code to enforce the provisions of this article.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
361/653
Legal agent means an employee or designee of a lender designated by the lender for purposes of receiving legal
notices relating to real property.
Lender means the owner and holder of a note and mortgage or other similar instrument that secures a debt upon
the property. "Lender" as used herein shall be synonymous with the term "mortgagee" for the purpose of this
article.
Maintenance agent means an employee or designee of a lender designated by the lender for purposes of
maintaining the condition of real property. This shall be synonymous with a "property management company" or
similar entity designated by the lender as being responsible for the maintenance of the abandoned real property.
Mortgagee shall mean:
(1)
The holder of an indebtedness or obligee of a non-monetary obligation secured by a mortgage or any person
designated or authorized to act on behalf of such holder;
(2)
Any person claiming through a mortgagee as successor; and
(3)
Any person identified as such in a recorded document which has been released, assigned, or superseded of
record. For the purpose of this article, "mortgagee" shall be synonymous with the term "lender."
(Ord. No. 12O-04-109, § 1, 4-30-2012)
Sec. 10-33. - Establishment of a registry.
The city hereby establishes a registry cataloging each abandoned property within the city, containing the
information required by this article.
(1)
The city shall use the information collected in the registry to establish a schedule for the monitoring of
abandoned property located within the city.
(Ord. No. 12O-04-109, § 1, 4-30-2012)
Sec. 10-34. - Registration of real property.
(a)
Upon the default of a mortgagor, a lender holding a mortgage on real property located within the city shall, prior
to the issuance of a notice of default, perform an inspection of the property that is the security for the mortgage.
If, upon inspection, the property is found to be vacant or shows evidence of vacancy, it shall be classified as an
abandoned property and the lender shall, within ten (10) days of the inspection, register the property with the
city. A separate registration is required for each abandoned property.
(b)
If the property is occupied but remains in default, it shall be inspected by the lender monthly until either:
(1)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
362/653
The mortgagor or other party remedies the default; or
(2)
It is found to be vacant or shows evidence of vacancy at which time it is deemed to be abandoned, and the lender
shall, within ten (10) days of that inspection, register the property with the city.
(c)
Registration pursuant to this section shall contain: the property owner's name, the address of the property, the
folio or parcel control number, the lender's name, the lender's loan number and the name, address, telephone
number and email address for the lender's maintenance and legal agents. The city may require such other
information the city deems necessary to fulfill the intent and purpose of this section. The lender's legal agent and
maintenance agent may be the same person.
(d)
The city shall charge a non-refundable annual registration fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per
abandoned real property, which shall accompany the required registration form and/or renewal registration form
provided by the city for the filing of information of each property listed in the registry. The annual registration
fee shall correspond to the fiscal year of the city and renewal of the registration must be completed prior to
October 1 of any applicable year so long as the property remains abandoned. A failure to timely register shall be
subject to the issuance of a citation upon the lender and a civil penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00). The
renewal of the registration form with its accompanying fee each year shall be the responsibility of the lender and
a failure to timely renew shall also be subject to the issuance of a citation upon the lender and a civil penalty of
five hundred dollars ($500.00). Said penalty(s) shall be used towards satisfying any city liens upon the premises
that accrued prior to the filing in the registry and any excess penalty moneys shall be retained by the city.
(e)
In the event that the information required during the registration has changed, the lender shall update the registry
to reflect the updated information within ten (10) days of the change, including the status of the proceedings
initiated by the lender, if any, to foreclose the mortgage on a registered property. Any notice of violation or legal
process which has been delivered or served prior to the receipt by the city of an amended registration form shall
be deemed effective service. Registration pursuant to this section shall not be transferable.
(f)
Properties subject to this section shall remain under the annual registration requirement, security and
maintenance standards enumerated in this section as long as they remain abandoned.
(g)
A lender's registration of a property shall constitute the consent of the lender for the city's enforcement officer to
enter the premises for inspection purposes in the limited circumstances defined in section 10-35(a).
(h)
Any action or case initiated pursuant to this section may be presented to the code enforcement board, court, or
other entity or person with jurisdiction even if, prior to a hearing, the property is no longer abandoned or vacant
or the violation has been remedied.
(Ord. No. 12O-04-109, § 1, 4-30-2012)
Sec. 10-35. - Inspection and posting.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
363/653
(a)
The city's enforcement officer may physically enter the premises of a registered property in the normal course of
property inspections under the same legal authority possessed by the lender to enter upon such property, not
more often than once every month, for the purpose of examining the property to ensure that the property is
properly secured and is not a danger to the surrounding area. The city shall notify the maintenance agent of the
date and time of the proposed inspection at least ten (10) days prior to entering the property. The lender's
maintenance agent may accompany the city's inspectors during such inspection.
(b)
The city's enforcement officer may issue notices requiring a lender to correct a violation[s] of the City Code,
observed by the city during the inspection.
(c)
The abandoned property shall be posted with the name, address and twenty-four-hour contact phone number of a
local maintenance agent. The posted sign shall be no less than eight (8) inches by ten (10) inches or any larger
than four (4) square feet. All written information thereupon shall be clear, legible and update as required within
ten (10) days of any change of information. The posting shall contain the following language:
THIS PROPERTY IS MANAGED BY:
[Insert Name and Address]
TO REPORT PROBLEMS OR CONCERNS CALL:
[Insert Direct Phone Number]
The posting shall be placed in a manner so that it is visible either on the interior of a building facing the front, or
if no building exists on the property then on a stake of sufficient size to support the posting in a location as close
as possible to the front of the property.
(Ord. No. 12O-04-109, § 1, 4-30-2012)
Sec. 10-36. - Maintenance requirements.
The lender must comply with any and all applicable laws relative to the abandoned property including, but not
limited to, state statutes, federal codes, county codes, building codes, and city codes in order to properly
maintain the abandoned property in a secure manner, which shall include but not be limited to, the following
requirements for so long as the building remains abandoned.
(1)
Properties subject to this article shall be kept free of weeds, overgrown grass, brush, dead vegetation, trash, junk,
debris, building materials, any accumulation of newspapers, circulars, flyers, notices, except those required by
federal, state, or local law, discarded personal items included, but not limited to, furniture, clothing, large and
small appliances, printed material or any other items that give the appearance that the property is abandoned.
(2)
Properties shall be maintained free of graffiti or similar markings by removal or painting over with an exterior
grade paint that matches the color of the exterior structure.
(3)
Front, side, and rear yard landscaping shall be maintained in accordance with the standards enumerated in the
City Code at the time registration was required.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
364/653
(4)
Landscape shall include, but not be limited to, grass, ground covers, bushes, trees, shrubs, hedges or similar
plantings, decorative rock or bark or artificial turf/sod designed specifically for residential installation.
Landscape shall not include weeds, gravel, broken concrete, asphalt or similar material.
(5)
Maintenance shall include, but not be limited to, watering, irrigation, cutting, and mowing of required landscape
and removal of all vegetative trimmings.
(6)
Pools and spas shall be maintained so the water remains free and clear of pollutants and debris and shall be
sanitary. Pools and spas shall comply with the enclosure requirements of the City Code, the county code, and the
Florida Building Code, as amended from time to time.
(7)
The structural integrity of any buildings, stairs and steps shall be reasonably maintained.
(8)
The fences and gates shall be reasonably maintained and secure.
(9)
All doors and windows shall be secured such that all building openings are closed, secure, weather tight
(hurricane proof, etc.), and rodent proof as may be required by City Code.
(Ord. No. 12O-04-109, § 1, 4-30-2012)
Sec. 10-37. - Repair and remedies.
(a)
The city may notify the maintenance agent for any property listed in the registry that is not maintained in
accordance with the provisions enumerated in section 10-36. If, after providing such notice, the property remains
unsecured or vandalized, in violation of the City Code, or in disrepair or uninhabitable as described in section
10-36, the city may, but is not required to, initiate repairs. Pursuant to F.S. § 162.09, the city is not obligated to
maintain or continue any repairs it has initiated.
(b)
The city may recover the full amount of the cost of such repairs from the lender. Such costs shall be assessed
against the property and shall constitute a lien on such property equal in priority to real property taxes, including
any post lis pendens assessment filed by the city, which shall be deemed valid, during a foreclosure proceeding,
and shall be superior to all mortgage liens and other liens or judgments against such property, which must be
satisfied in full upon sale of the property occurring as a result of the foreclosure proceeding or upon settlement
or dismissal in the proceeding, provided that:
(1)
The lender's legal agent (in addition to the lender's maintenance agent) is provided notice of the citation.
(2)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
365/653
The lender has been afforded the opportunity to be heard and to dispute the evidence or present evidence of its
intent to secure and repair the property; and
(3)
The property is not brought into compliance by the lender within the required timeframe, then the city may
proceed to initiate and complete repairs and secure the property, and all associated costs will be imposed as a
special assessment lien upon the lender. The city may also impose monitoring fees as necessary to justify the
costs of code enforcement officers relative to abandoned properties.
(c)
This section does not prohibit the city from inspecting property and enforcing its laws or from exercising any
other remedies available to the city as provided by law. Additionally, if the real property poses an immediate
danger to the public health, safety, and welfare, the city may take any authorized action provided by law, and the
costs of correcting the immediate danger shall hold the same status as an assessment provided in this section.
(Ord. No. 12O-04-109, § 1, 4-30-2012)
Sec. 10-38. - Violations of article/penalties.
It shall be unlawful for any lender to fail to comply with any provision of this article. Failure of a lender to
properly maintain the abandoned property is a violation of the City Code which may be subject to one (1) or
more of the following remedies: the issuance of a citation, or of a notice of violation/notice of hearing by code
enforcement, abatement of a nuisance, action of the unsafe structures board, or the application of any other
remedy or legal proceeding available to the city to ensure compliance with this section. In any instance where
the city takes action, the city shall provide the lender's legal agent with the same notice as the property owner.
Failure to comply with the requirements of this notice shall be unlawful and subject to penalty of the City Code
and the Florida Building Code as applicable.
(Ord. No. 12O-04-109, § 1, 4-30-2012)
Sec. 10-39. - Immunity from prosecution.
Any enforcement officer shall be immune from prosecution, civil or criminal, for reasonable, good faith entry
upon the subject abandoned property while in the discharge of duties imposed by this article.
(Ord. No. 12O-04-109, § 1, 4-30-2012)

ARTICLE II. - KOSHER FOODS
Footnotes:
--- (2) ---
Editor's note— Ord. No. 79-124, §§ 1—7, adopted May 29, 1979, was nonamendatory of the Code; hence,
inclusion of said provisions herein as Art. II, §§ 11-31—11-37 is at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 11-31. - Definitions.
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall, for the purpose of this article, have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them as follows:
Food. All articles used for food, drink, confectionary or condiment by man, whether simple, mixed or
compound.
Food establishment. Any place where foods are sold, kept, stored, offered or exposed for sale, manufactured,
slaughtered, prepared or processed as being kosher.
Food handler. Any person whose duties bring him in contact with foods whereby such handling might convey
disease to the consumer.
Kosher. Sanctioned by the orthodox Hebrew religious requirements.
Kosher market. A food establishment which advertises itself as trading or selling kosher foods.
(Ord. No. 79-124, § 1, 5-29-79)
Sec. 11-32. - Regulations concerning retail sales in kosher meat markets.
A person who, with intent to defraud, sells or exposes for sale any meat or meat preparation, article of food or
food product and falsely represents the same to be kosher, whether such meat or meat preparation, article of food
or food product be raw or prepared for human consumption, or as having been prepared under and of a product
sanctioned by the orthodox Hebrew religious requirements, either by direct statement orally or in writing, or
falsely represents any food product or the contents of any package or container to be so constituted and prepared,
by having or permitting to be inscribed thereon the word "Kosher" in any language; or sells or exposes for sale
in the same place of business both kosher and nonkosher meat or meat preparation, either raw or prepared for
human consumption, who fails to indicate on his window signs and all display advertising, in block letters at
least four (4) inches in height, "Kosher and nonkosher meat sold here"; or who exposes for sale in any show
window or place of business both kosher and nonkosher meat or meat preparations either raw or prepared for
human consumption, who fails to display over each kind of meat or meat preparation so exposed a sign in block
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
367/653
letters at least four (4) inches in height reading "Kosher meat," or "Nonkosher meat" as the case may be, or who
displays on his window, door, or in his place of business, or in handbills or other printed matter distributed in or
outside of his place of business, words or letters in Hebraic characters or any sign, emblem, insignia, six-pointed
star, or symbol or mark in simulation of same, the display of which might reasonably be calculated to deceive or
lead a person to believe that a representation, expressed or implied, is being made that the meat or meat
preparation exposed for sale is kosher and in conformity with prescribed orthodox Hebrew religious
requirements shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in Section 125.69, Florida Statutes.
(Ord. No. 79-124, § 2, 5-29-79)
Sec. 11-33. - Regulations concerning sales in restaurants.
A person who, with intent to defraud, sells or exposes for sale in any hotel, restaurant or other place where food
products are sold for consumption on the premises, any meat or meat preparation or any article of food or food
preparation and falsely represents the same to be kosher or as having been prepared in accordance with the
orthodox Hebrew religious requirements, either by direct statements, orally or in writing, or by the display of the
word "Kosher" in English or Hebrew letters or by the display of any sign or mark in simulation of such word, or
by the display of any insignia, six-pointed star, or any mark which might reasonably be calculated to deceive or
lead a reasonable person to believe that a representation is being made that the food sold is kosher or prepared in
accordance with the orthodox Hebrew religious requirements; or sells or exposes for sale in such hotel,
restaurant or such other place both kosher and nonkosher food or food preparations for consumption on the
premises not prepared in accordance with the Jewish ritual or not sanctioned by the orthodox Hebrew religious
requirements and who fails to display on his window signs and all display advertising in block letters at least
four (4) inches in height "Kosher and nonkosher food served here"; or who displays within or outside such hotel,
restaurant or other place or on a window or door thereof, or in handbills or other printed matter distributed in or
outside such hotel, restaurant or other place, words or letters in Hebraic characters or any sign, emblem, insignia,
symbol or mark in simulation of same, the display of which might reasonably be calculated to deceive or lead a
reasonable person to believe that a representation is being made that the food sold or offered for sale is kosher or
prepared in accordance with the orthodox Hebrew religious requirements shall, upon conviction thereof, be
punished as provided in Section 125.69, Florida Statutes.
(Ord. No. 79-124, § 3, 5-29-79)
Sec. 11-34. - Misbranding.
A person who willfully marks, stamps, tags, brands, labels or in any other way or by any other means of
identification, represents or causes to be marked, stamped, tagged, branded, labeled or represented as kosher or
as having been prepared in accordance with the orthodox Hebrew religious requirements or as having been
approved or sanctioned by or prepared under the direction or supervision of a rabbi or other person vested with
or designated by rabbinical authority, any meats, meat preparations, articles of food or food products not kosher,
not so prepared or not so approved, sanctioned or prepared, as the case may be, or willfully removes, defaces,
obliterates, covers, alters or destroys or causes to be removed, defaced, obliterated, covered, altered or destroyed
the original slaughterhouse plumba or any other mark, stamp, tag, brand label or any other means of
identification customarily affixed to meats, meat preparations, food or food products to indicate that such meats,
meat preparations, food or food products are kosher or have been prepared in accordance with the orthodox
Hebrew religious requirements or have been approved or sanctioned by or prepared under the direction of a
rabbi or other person vested with or designated by rabbinical authority, or, knowingly sells, disposes of or has in
his possession, for the purpose of resale to any person as kosher, any meats, meat preparations, food or food
products not having affixed thereto the original slaughterhouse plumba or any other mark, stamp, tag, brand
label or other means of identification customarily employed to indicate that such meats, meat preparations, food
or food products are kosher or have been prepared in accordance with the orthodox Hebrew religious
requirements or any meats, meat preparations, food or food products to which such plumba, mark, stamp, tag,
brand label or other means of identification has or have been fraudulently affixed, or does or causes to be done
any of the acts mentioned in this section for the purpose or with the intent of violating or causing to be violated
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
368/653
the provisions of sections 11-32 and 11-33 shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in Section
125.69, Florida Statutes.
(Ord. No. 79-124, § 4, 5-29-79)
Sec. 11-35. - Kosher food inspector.
It shall be the duty of the kosher food inspector to inspect food, food products, beverages and merchandise held
out to be kosher and premises held out as dealing in kosher food, food products, beverages and merchandise and
to enforce the provisions of sections 11-32, 11-33, 11-34 of this article. The kosher food inspector shall not
accept any consideration or value in the food establishment he serves as kosher food inspector. Failure to adhere
to this requirement shall subject the kosher food inspector to discharge. Any person who offers or gives or
promises the kosher food inspector any consideration or value with an intent or purpose to influence the
performance of any act or omission to act by the kosher food inspector shall be guilty of bribery and punished
under the laws of the State of Florida.
(Ord. No. 79-124, § 5, 5-29-79)
Sec. 11-36. - Tagging of food products.
Whenever the inspector finds, or has probable cause to believe, that any food or food product is adulterated or
misbranded within the meaning of this article, he may affix to such food or food product a tag or other
appropriate marking, giving notice that such food or food product is, or is suspected of being, adulterated or
misbranded and has been quarantined, and warning all persons not to remove or dispose of such food or food
product by sale or otherwise until permission for removal or disposal is given by the inspector or his duly
authorized representative. It shall be a violation of this article for any person to remove or dispose of such
quarantined food or food product by sale or otherwise without such permission.
(Ord. No. 79-124, § 6, 5-29-79)
Sec. 11-37. - Penalties for article violation.
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars
($500.00) or be imprisoned for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days or be both so fined and imprisoned. Each
such violation shall be considered a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
(Ord. No. 79-124, § 7, 5-29-79)
Secs. 11-38—11-45. - Reserved.
ARTICLE III. - HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICES DEPARTMENT
Sec. 11-46. - Department created.
There is hereby created the health and social services department of the city.
(Ord. No. 79-140, § 1, 8-13-79)
Sec. 11-47. - Director.
The director of the department of health and social services shall supervise and direct the department of health
and social services.
(Ord. No. 79-140, § 2, 8-13-79; Ord. No. 89-147, § 1, 7-10-89)
Sec. 11-48. - Duties and responsibilities of department.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
369/653
The duties and responsibilities of the health and social services department are as follows:
(a)
To educate, encourage and assist in bringing health programs to the public;
(b)
To assist in the maintenance of the well-being of our citizens by bringing programs for the prevention and
elimination of disease;
(c)
To coordinate and review existing and project health programs available to the public;
(d)
To communicate with private and public health agencies to help expand health programs;
(e)
To make available diagnostic and screening tests without cost, or for a nominal fee for those least able to afford
such programs;
(f)
To assist the general public to utilize existing private and governmental programs available to help maintain
good health;
(g)
To petition for financial assistance to help carry out these programs;
(h)
To provide for a social service program to include transportation and informational assistance to the indigent and
elderly entitled to such service;
(i)
To establish an informational bank to serve citizens in medicare, medicaid, social security and human resources;
(j)
To identify obstacle areas that handicapped persons face in city public areas within the city;
(k)
To identify services that are both needed and/or available to handicapped residents within the city; and
(l)
To generally suggest legislation and/or administrative action that would benefit handicapped residents within the
city.
(Ord. No. 79-140, § 3, 8-13-79; Ord. No. 98O-6-124, § 1, 6-29-98)

(Ord. No. 79-140, § 4, 8-13-79; Ord. No. 79-168, § 1, 12-12-79; Ord. No. 98O-6-124, § 1, 6-29-98)

ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY

DIVISION 2. - LEASE RENEWAL
Footnotes:
--- (2) ---
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-113, adopted April 28, 1980, did not specifically amend this Code; hence,
codification herein of §§ 1—4 of said ordinance as §§ 11½-46—11½-49 is at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 11½-46. - Findings of fact; purpose.
The following recitals are herein incorporated as part of this division:
(a)
A landlord by a unilateral, arbitrary and discriminatory act could refuse to renew the lease of an existing tenant
who has complied with all the terms and conditions of the existing lease and is willing to execute a renewal lease
containing new terms and conditions which are not unconscionable; and
(b)
An emergency situation exists in the City of Lauderhill due to an existing low vacancy rate of available rental
units throughout Broward County, said rate being less than fifty-six one-hundredths (0.56) percent as reported by
the Broward County Property Appraisers Office; and
(c)
The city council of the City of Lauderhill wishes to protect the rights of tenants due to the shortage of rental
units and said low vacancy rate, and, additionally, because of the general equity considerations that should be
considered by a landlord in making tenancy renewals; and
(d)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
375/653
The city council wishes to make it unlawful to refuse a tenancy renewal on a unilateral, arbitrary or
discriminatory basis.
(Ord. No. 80-113, § 1, 4-28-80)
Sec. 11½-47. - Definitions.
(a)
Landlord means any person or party or entity which owns rental real estate and any agent, servant and employee,
of an owner engaging in management, supervision, or maintenance of said real estate. Landlord shall, for all
purposes contained herein, include any tenant who sublets or assigns his interest in any dwelling or living space.
(b)
Tenant shall mean the person or persons currently in possession of the rental unit owned by the landlord.
(c)
Just cause means the following:
(1)
Failure on the part of the tenant to pay rent due and owing.
(2)
Disorderly or disturbing noises or conduct on the part of the tenant that destroy the peace and tranquility of
tenants, other persons living in or about the neighborhood.
(3)
Intentional or persistent neglect, damage, or injury by the tenant to the property of landlord.
(4)
Constant violation by the tenant of the rules and regulations of landlord. However, no rule or regulation shall be
valid unless signed by the tenant or incorporated in the lease and a copy given to tenant.
(5)
Substantial breach of the terms and conditions of the lease agreement by the tenant.
(6)
Any violation of law which violation would constitute grounds for eviction under any applicable law.
(d)
Unconscionable, as used in this article shall mean terms and conditions consistent with and similar to other
tenancy agreements already in effect for other similar or identical rental units at the development and/or rental
complex.
(Ord. No. 80-113, § 2, 4-28-80)
Sec. 11½-48. - Refusal to renew; terms of renewal agreement.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
376/653
A landlord shall be prohibited from refusing to renew an existing tenancy agreement with the tenant except for
just cause as defined in this division. Said new tenancy agreement shall contain terms and conditions which are
not unconscionable as defined in this division.
(Ord. No. 80-113, § 3, 4-28-80)
Sec. 11½-49. - Severability.
If any section of this division or subsection is declared to be unconstitutional, then that section or subsection
shall not affect or in any way obviate the legal effect of other sections and subsections of this division.
(Ord. No. 80-113, § 4, 4-28-80)
Sec. 11½-50. - Reserved.
ARTICLE III. - CONDOMINIUMS
Footnotes:
--- (3) ---
Editor's note— At the request of the city, Ord. No. 79-171, enacted Jan. 7, 1980, relating to the conversion of
rental units to condominiums is not included herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the
city clerk.
Sec. 11½-51. - Existing tenant's option to purchase when unit converted from rental status.
(a)
Developer's obligation. A developer who is creating a condominium by converting existing rental units shall be
obliged to reserve to an existing tenant that person's particular apartment, for purchase by that tenant, at any
discount price offered by the developer, for a period of not less than sixty (60) days prior to the expiration of that
tenant's legal tenancy.
(b)
Effective date; application. This section shall take effect as of May 7, 1980, and shall apply to all rental units
being sold as condominiums which have not yet been contracted for sale.
(c)
Sixty days' notice required. In no event may a tenant, after notification by the landlord of any reservation or
discount, be denied less than sixty (60) days from the date of said notice within which to purchase his or her
particular apartment at the discount price so offered.
(Ord. No. 80-121, §§ 1—3, 6-30-80)
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 80-121, enacted June 30, 1980, did not specifically amend this Code; however,
at the request of the city, §§ 1—3 of said ordinance are included herein, designation of said provisions as §
11½-51 is at the editor's discretion.

ARTICLE IV. - ASSISTANCE
Footnotes:
--- (4) ---
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
377/653
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 96O-105, adopted March 25, 1996, did not specifically amend the Code; hence,
codification of §§ 2(1)—(4), (6) and (7) as §§ 11½-61—11½-66 was at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 11½-61. - Definitions.
For the purposes of this article, the definitions contained in the State Housing Initiatives Partnership Act ("act"),
and Chapter 91-37, Florida Administrative Code, as they may be amended from time to time, are adopted herein
by reference.
(Ord. No. 96O-105, § 2(1), 3-25-96)
Sec. 11½-62. - Legislative intent.
The purposes of this article are to implement the act, including, without limitation, the following:
(1)
To increase the availability of affordable housing by combining local resources and cost-saving measures using a
local housing partnership(s), as applicable, and by using private and public funds to reduce the cost of housing;
(2)
To promote more compact urban development and to assist in achieving the growth management goals contained
in the adopted local comprehensive plan by allowing more efficient use of land so as to provide housing units
that are more affordable;
(3)
To establish a strong sense of community through increased social and economic integration;
(4)
To build the organizational and technical capacity of community-based organizations so as to optimize the role
of community-based organizations in the production of affordable housing;
(5)
To promote innovative design of eligible housing, and its supporting infrastructure, to provide for cost savings in
the provision of such housing; and
(6)
To promote expedited permit processing systems for affordable housing.
(Ord. No. 96O-105, § 2(2), 3-25-96)
Sec. 11½-63. - Local housing assistance program.
(a)
There is hereby created and established a local housing assistance program ("program") by the city, to be
implemented and administered by the city.
(b)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances

Sec. 11½-64. - Affordable housing assistance trust fund.
(a)
Pursuant to the requirements of the act, the city agrees to establish an affordable housing assistance trust fund

subject to the requirements of the act, and the city ordinance establishing the fund.

(Ord. No. 96O-105, § 2(4), 3-25-96)

committee ("committee"). Composition of the committee shall be as required by the act. Members of the
committee shall be appointed by resolution pursuant to the requirements of the article within thirty (30) days of
the effective date of this article. Members of this committee are permitted to simultaneously serve on other city
boards or committees.
(Ord. No. 96O-105, § 2(6), 3-25-96; Ord. No. 17O-02-109, § 1, 2-27-2017)
Sec. 11½-66. - Review and approval of affordable housing incentive plan.
(a)
Pursuant to the requirements of the act, within thirty (30) days of their receipt from the committee, the city shall
forward the committee's recommendations to the city commission for review and consideration. Following the
review of such recommendations, the city shall, pursuant to the requirements of the act, adopt an affordable
housing incentive plan ("incentive plan").
(b)
Upon adoption of the incentive plan, the city shall forward, or cause to be forwarded, a copy of the adopted
incentive plan to appropriate agencies pursuant to the requirements of the act.
(Ord. No. 96O-105, § 2(7), 3-25-96)
