Sec. 14-71. - Definitions.
[The following terms, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except
where context clearly indicates a different meaning:]
Alarm administrator shall mean the chief of police or his/her designee.
Alarm business shall mean any person engaged in selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering,
replacing, moving or installing any alarm system or in causing any alarm system to be sold, leased, maintained,
serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved or installed in or on any building, structure, facility or enclosed area.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
483/653
Alarm signal shall mean the audible sound or a transmission of a signal or a message as the result of the
activation of an alarm system or an audible alarm.
Alarm site shall mean a single premise or location served by an alarm system or systems.
Alarm system shall mean a device or system that emits, transmits, or relays a signal intended to summon, or that
would reasonably be expected to summon police and/or fire services of the city. Alarm systems shall not
include:
(1)
Vehicle alarms unless the vehicle is a permanent part of the site.
(2)
An alarm that is designed to alert only the inhabitants of the premises but which does not transmit a signal to a
monitoring company, or that does not have an audible local alarm (i.e. internal alarm only).
Alarm user shall mean a person(s), firm, partnership, corporation, association, limited partnership, sole
proprietorship, organization, company, or any other entity who owns the property where an alarm system is
installed.
Audible alarm shall mean a device designed for the detection of unauthorized entry on premises which generates
an audible sound when it is activated.
False alarm shall mean activation or transmission of any alarm signal caused by human error, mechanical or
electronic malfunction, negligence of the alarm user or the alarm user's employees, whether or not the exact
cause of the alarm activation is determined, or any other activation or transmission of any alarm signal where no
actual or attempted criminal act, life-threatening situation, loss of property situation or fire exists. Severe
weather, power outages, transmission line malfunctions, acts of God, malicious acts of persons not under the
control of the user, or any other cause clearly beyond the control of the alarm user will be considered in
determining if an alarm activation was false, and whether or not any fee, warning or other punitive action will be
taken against the alarm user as provided for by this article.
Local alarm shall mean an alarm system that emits a signal at an alarm site that is audible or visible from the
exterior of the structure.
Notice shall mean written notice, given either by certified mail, return receipt requested, by personal service
upon the addressee, or the posting of a notice on the property.
Permit holder shall mean the person designated in the application as required in this article, who is responsible
for responding to alarms and giving access to the site.
Person shall mean any natural person, individual, any firm, partnership, association, limited partnership, sole
proprietorship, corporation, organization or any business entity whatsoever.
Police chief means the police chief of the city.
(Ord. No. 96O-164, § 1, 1-13-97; Ord. No. 99O-4-122, § 1, 4-26-99; Ord. No. 99O-6-130, § 1, 6-28-99; Ord.
No. 12O-11-155, § 1, 12-10-2012)
Sec. 14-72. - Posting of notices; deactivation of system.
(a)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
484/653
It is unlawful to maintain on any premises any alarm system or audible alarm unless it has posted in the main
entrance to the premises a prominent, conspicuous notice of the telephone numbers of the person or persons
authorized to enter the premises and deactivate such alarm system or audible alarm.
(b)
It is further unlawful to maintain any alarm system or audible alarm that does not deactivate within fifteen (15)
minutes of its activation in a residential district and within thirty (30) minutes of its activation in a business
and/or industrial district. In the event that the person(s) authorized to enter the premises and deactivate such
alarm system or audible alarm cannot be contacted at the posted telephone numbers or, if contacted, fail to
appear within thirty (30) minutes of such contact; or if such alarm system or audible alarm does not deactivate
within the time period specified above, then the chief of police may order the contractor selected by the city to
disconnect such alarm system, as the case may be.
(Ord. No. 96O-164, § 1, 1-13-97; Ord. No. 99O-4-122, § 1, 4-26-99; Ord. No. 12O-11-155, § 2, 12-10-2012)
Sec. 14-73. - Unlawful/lawful activation.
It is unlawful for any person to activate any alarm system or audible alarm except in the event of an actual or
attempted assault, burglary, robbery or fire.
(Ord. No. 96O-164, § 1, 1-13-97; Ord. No. 99O-4-122, § 1, 4-26-99)
Sec. 14-74. - Procedures and fees for police and/or fire responses to false alarms.
(a)
The alarm user shall be subject to warnings and fees depending on the number of false alarms emitted from an
alarm system within any twelve-month period based on the following schedule:
Number of False Alarms Fee
First and second alarm No fee
Third alarm $25.00
Fourth alarm $50.00
Fifth and subsequent alarms $100.00
For purposes of the billing schedule above, multi-unit parcels, whether commercial or residential, shall be billed
separately to each alarm user based on the alarms per unit. Unpaid bills for false alarms issued between January
1, 2013 and the enactment of this section shall be retroactively credited to be in conformance with the billing
schedule above.
If police respond to a false alarm which is in violation of section 14-72, the above-stated fees shall be doubled.
This fee schedule shall apply to each alarm user at a particular location.
(b)
It is unlawful for any alarm user to refuse or fail to pay any cost assessed for deactivating an alarm pursuant to
this section.
(c)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
485/653
It is unlawful for any alarm user to refuse or fail to pay fees or fines associated with the violations of this
section.
(d)
Fines and fees not paid within thirty (30) days of the billing date will be assessed a ten (10) percent penalty on
the outstanding balance. All fines and fees not paid after ninety (90) days will be turned over to a collection
agency selected by the city for collection. The violator will be responsible for all costs associated with this
action up to and including legal fees.
(Ord. No. 96O-164, § 1, 1-13-97; Ord. No. 99O-4-122, § 1, 4-26-99; Ord. No. 12O-11-155, § 3, 12-10-2012;
Ord. No. 14O-04-115, § 1, 5-12-2014; Ord. No. 17O-04-121, § 1, 5-8-2017)
Sec. 14-75. - False alarm 911 calls.
A 911 call which is determined by the responding officer or dispatcher to have been caused by inadvertent
dialing, false reporting of an emergency pursuant to section 14-71(e), or other such misuse, shall constitute a
false alarm and shall be charged to the registered owner or lessee of the telephone from which the 911 call was
made, in accordance with the fee schedule set forth in section 14-74.
(Ord. No. 96O-164, § 1, 1-13-97)

Sec. 14-77. - Identification of interior motion by zones required.
All alarm systems installed after January 13, 1997:
(a)
In addition to door or window sensors, shall be capable of identifying interior motion by zones and notifying the
monitoring station as to which zones are activated; and
(b)
Shall be capable of operating for at least one (1) hour without incoming power and shall be equipped so as to
protect the alarm system in the event of a power surge.
If the alarm system is capable of notifying the monitoring station by zones, the monitoring system shall not
notify the city if only one (1) zone is activated.
(Ord. No. 96O-164, § 1, 1-13-97)
Sec. 14-78. - Liability.
The city police department shall be under no obligation to respond to any message or signal transmitted in
violation of this article, and the city, the city police department, the chief of police of the city, and all officers,
employees and agents of the city shall not be liable, either civilly or criminally, for any failure to so respond.
(Ord. No. 96O-164, § 1, 1-13-97; Ord. No. 99O-4-122, § 1, 4-26-99)
Sec. 14-79. - Entry on premises.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
486/653
The chief of police of the city; all officers, employees and agents of the city police department; and the
contractor are hereby authorized to enter upon any premises in the city, at any time of the day or night, for the
purpose of enforcing the provisions of section 14-74.
(Ord. No. 96O-164, § 1, 1-13-97)
Sec. 14-80. - Appeals.
Anyone liable for a false alarm fee may appeal that fee in the following manner:
(a)
Written notice of the appeal must be filed with the chief of police within ten (10) days following the issuance of
the notice of false alarm. The appeal shall state the name and address of the appellant, the date of the violation,
and the reason why, in the opinion of the appellant, the appealed action should be reversed.
(b)
The appeal will be heard by the chief of police or the designee of the chief of police within fifteen (15) days
following the date of receipt of appeal by the chief of police.
(c)
The chief of police or his or her designee shall issue a written decision of his or her determination.
(d)
In the event that the decision shall be adverse to the appellant, the appellant may, within thirty (30) days of the
issuance of the written decision, file a petition for a writ of certiorari with the circuit court of the county.
(e)
While the appellate process is pending, no adverse action shall be taken against the appellant if the appellant
shall have posted with the city, at the time that the written notice of appeal is filed, a bond equal to the amount
claimed by the city.
(Ord. No. 96O-164, § 1, 1-13-97)
ARTICLE V. - BINGO
Sec. 14-81. - Definitions.
The following terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Bingo card means and refers to that flat piece of paper or thin pasteboard employed by players engaged in the
game of bingo. The bingo card shall have not fewer than twenty-four (24) playing numbers printed on it. These
playing numbers shall range from one (1) through seventy-five (75), inclusive. More than one (1) set of bingo
numbers may be printed on any single piece of paper.
Bingo game means and refers to the activity, commonly known as "bingo," in which participants pay a sum of
money for the use of one (1) or more bingo cards. When the game commences, numbers are drawn by chance,
one (1) by one (1), and announced. The players cover or mark those numbers on the bingo cards which they
have purchased until a player receives a given order of numbers in sequence that has been preannounced for that
particular game. This player calls out "bingo" and is declared the winner of a predetermined prize. More than
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
487/653
one (1) game may be played upon a bingo card, and numbers called for one (1) game may be used for a
succeeding game or games.
Charitable, nonprofit, or veterans' organization means an organization which has qualified for exemption from
federal income tax as an exempt organization under the provisions of Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue
Code of 1954 or Section 528 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, which is engaged in charitable,
civic, community, benevolent, religious, or scholastic works or other similar activities, and which has been in
existence and active for a period of three (3) years or more.
Condominium association means any legal entity whose membership primarily consists of condominium owners
within the city.
Lessor means or refers to any person or persons, partnership, or Florida corporation renting to, or providing
space for, an operator or granting a lease to an operator for a period of not less than one (1) year. The lease must
provide a rental rate for the premises which does not exceed the rental charged for similar premises in the same
locale, and does not provide for payment of a percentage of the proceeds generated.
Objects means a set of seventy-five (75) balls or other precision shapes that are imprinted with letters and
numbers in such a way that numbers one (1) through fifteen (15) are marked with the letter "B," numbers sixteen
(16) through thirty (30) are marked with the letter "I," numbers thirty-one (31) through forty-five (45) are
marked with the letter "N," numbers forty-six (46) through sixty (60) are marked with the letter "G," and
numbers sixty-one (61) through seventy-five (75) are marked with the letter "O."
Operator means any person, partnership, corporation, or other legal entity which operates a bingo game, or bingo
games.
Player means any person paying money to the operator in order to participate in a bingo game.
Prize means any cash or other property or thing of value awarded to a player.
Rack means the container in which the objects are placed after being drawn and announced.
Receptacle means the container from which the objects are drawn or ejected.
Session means a designated set of games played in a day or part of a day.
(Ord. No. 95-122, § 1, 4-24-95)
Sec. 14-82. - Operator's permit.
(a)
It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate a bingo game or series of bingo games without having first obtained a
valid permit, which shall be obtained from the code compliance division.
(b)
The cost of such permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
(c)
The permit shall be effective for a period of not more than twelve (12) months from the date of issuance, and
shall expire on September 30 of each year.
(d)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
488/653
The applicant shall provide the following information under oath each year.
(1)
[Type of operator.]
a.
If the operator is a corporation, the names and addresses of its officers and directors and a certified copy of its
articles of incorporation and bylaws;
b.
If the operator is a partnership, the names and addresses of all living, if any, partners and a copy of the
partnership agreement; and
c.
If the operator is not a corporation or partnership, the names and addresses of all persons who constitute the
operator, and any agreement or document under which the operator exists or conducts itself.
(2)
A detailed description of the charitable, civic, community, benevolent, religious or scholastic works in which the
operator is involved and the endeavors to which the proceeds from the bingo games shall be donated.
(3)
The address of the premises in which the operator performs, conducts or supervises bingo games, and the days
of the week on which the operator performs, conducts or supervises bingo games. If the days are changed, a
supplemental statement setting forth the new days must be filed with the code enforcement division of the
mayor's office prior to such change.
(4)
The names and addresses of all persons, firms, corporations, or business entities owning, directly or indirectly,
ten (10) percent or more of the operator; and
(5)
A financial statement of the operator evidencing the amount and sources of its previous year's gross revenue and
the distributees with the amount of its previous year's distributions. This statement must be audited. The
information supplied shall cover the period of the operator's most recently concluded fiscal year.
(e)
The city police department shall conduct a background investigation of the applicant and shall report to the code
compliance division the results of the background investigation and recommend approval or denial of the
application.
(f)
At the expiration of the permit, a new application shall be required, which shall contain all of the information
required for issuance of the original permit, and an investigation will be conducted by the city police department
prior to the issuance of a new permit.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
489/653
(g)
Any operator who is operating a bingo game or bingo games on April 24, 1995, shall have thirty (30) days from
this date to apply for an operator's permit and sixty (60) days from this date to be issued a permit, or shall be in
violation of this article.
(Ord. No. 95-122, § 1, 4-24-95)
Sec. 14-83. - Lessor's permit.
(a)
It shall be unlawful for any lessor to rent or provide space to, or permit its premises to be utilized by, an operator
without first obtaining a valid permit from the code compliance division.
(b)
In order to receive such permit, the lessor shall tender to the code compliance division a sketch of the premises
to be used, showing the square footage that will be used for bingo games and further showing the availability of
minimum off-street parking spaces, as required by the land development regulations. In addition, the lessor shall
provide the following information under oath each year:
(1)
Complete information as to the rentals and other financial benefits received from any operators using the
premises during the preceding twelve (12) months.
(2)
[Type of lessor.]
a.
If the lessor is a corporation, the names and addresses of its officers and directors and a true and correct copy of
its articles of incorporation and bylaws;
b.
If the lessor is a partnership, the names and addresses of all the partners and a copy of the partnership agreement;
c.
If the operator is not a corporation or partnership, the names and addresses of all persons who constitute the
operator, and any agreement or document under which the operator exists or conducts itself.
(3)
The addresses of all premises leased or owned by the lessor in which bingo games are performed, the days of the
week in which any and all operators perform, conduct or supervise bingo games, and the names and addresses of
all bingo operators.
(4)
The names and addresses of all persons, firms, corporations or business entities owning, directly or indirectly,
ten (10) percent or more of lessor.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
490/653
(5)
A financial statement of the lessor evidencing the amount and sources of the previous year's gross revenue and
all expenses paid. This statement shall be audited.
(6)
The name or names of the proposed operator(s) at the premises for which the permit will be issued and a detailed
statement setting forth such operator'(s)' legal qualifications to conduct bingo games under state law.
(7)
The days of the week on which each operator shall be operating.
(8)
If the days of the week on which each operator shall be operating shall change, or if an operator shall cease to
operate the lessor's space, or if a lease shall be issued to a new operator, the lessor shall amend its application
within seven (7) days thereafter. If a lease to a new operator shall be issued, the annual fee shall be increased to
reflect this change. No increase shall be pro-rata.
(c)
The cost of the permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per day for each day of the week that the lessor leases to an
operator.
(d)
The permit shall be effective for a period of not more than twelve (12) months from the date of issuance, and
shall expire on September 30 of each year.
(e)
The city police department shall conduct a background investigation of the applicant and shall report to the code

application.
(f)
At the expiration of the permit, a new application shall be required, which shall contain all of the information
required for issuance of the original permit, and an investigation will be conducted by the city police department
prior to the issuance of a new permit.
(Ord. No. 95-122, § 1, 4-24-95)
Sec. 14-84. - Revocation of permit.
(a)
A permit may be revoked at any time by the code compliance division if it has reason to believe that:
(1)
The grounds for issuing the permit no longer exists;
(2)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
491/653
The permittee is operating in violation of this article or in violation of state law; or
(3)
The permit was secured by fraud or misrepresentation.
(b)
The operator or lessor shall cease to operate any bingo games or lease to bingo operators on the date of
revocation of the permit.
(c)
The permittee shall be given written notice specifying the reasons for revocation concurrently with the
revocation. The notice shall be given by United States Mail or by hand delivery.
(Ord. No. 95-122, § 1, 4-24-95)
Sec. 14-85. - Maintenance of records.
(a)
Each operator shall maintain adequate records at the place where the bingo game or games is operated for a
minimum of three (3) years of the daily bingo activity on a per-game basis, which shall include:
(1)
Gross game receipts and all income from any source, including, but not limited to, admission charges;
(2)
All payout for prizes, whether in cash or merchandise;
(3)
Any and all operating expenses; and
(4)
Net proceeds.
These records shall be made available for immediate inspection by the city at reasonable times during normal
business hours, including while bingo games are in progress.
(b)
Each lessor shall maintain records for a minimum of three (3) years of all income and expenses from such leases
or rentals or other source relating to bingo games, and they shall require their operator to furnish information to
them as enumerated in paragraph 14-85(a) on a monthly basis for all bingo activity on their premises. All such
records shall be made available to the city for immediate inspection during normal business hours.
(c)
Each lessor shall maintain records for a minimum of three (3) years of all operators who receive income from
the lessor and the amount of income paid to the operator and received from the operator. These records shall be
made available to the city for immediate inspection during normal business hours and shall be submitted to the
city annually upon reapplication for a permit.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
492/653
(d)
Each lessor shall immediately inform the code compliance division whenever it adds a new operator or
eliminates an existing operator.
(Ord. No. 95-122, § 1, 4-24-95)
Sec. 14-86. - Conduct of games.
(a)
Bingo games may be held only on the following premises:
(1)
Property owned by the charitable, nonprofit, or veterans' organization.
(2)
Property owned by the charitable, nonprofit, or veterans' organization that will benefit by the proceeds.
(3)
Property leased according to the terms of section 14-81.
(4)
With respect to bingo games conducted by a condominium association, property owned by the association, or
property which is common area located within the condominium.
(b)
Fifty (50) percent of all games leased by the lessor must consist of operators that are located in the city.
(Ord. No. 95-122, § 1, 4-24-95)
Sec. 14-87. - Forfeiture of permit.
Any person, association, partnership, corporation or other legal entity which shall be convicted under any
section of this article shall forfeit any permit issued pursuant to this article and be ineligible to apply for any
subsequent permit. A suspended sentence, probation or withholding of adjudication shall result in a forfeiture of
any permit issued pursuant to this article and the offending party shall be ineligible to apply for any subsequent
permit.
(Ord. No. 95-122, § 1, 4-24-95)
Sec. 14-88. - Penalty.
Any person convicted of violating any portion of this article shall be punished in accordance with section 1-8 of
the Code.
(Ord. No. 95-122, § 1, 4-24-95)
Secs. 14-89, 14-90. - Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. - SOLICITORS AND PEDDLERS
DIVISION 1. - STREET SOLICITATION
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
493/653
Sec. 14-91. - Findings and purpose.
It is found and declared that:
(1)
The purpose of the public streets and sidewalks is for use by vehicular and pedestrian traffic.
(2)
The prohibition of street and sidewalk solicitation is necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the
travelling public. Municipalities are granted the power to protect the health, safety, and welfare of its residents
by preventing the obstruction of free and safe movement of vehicular traffic on its roads in accordance with the
Florida Constitution, Article VIII, Section 2(b), and F.S. §§ 316.2045 and 337.406.
(3)
The regulations contained in this article do not restrict the pure speech rights of organizations, but merely
regulate the activities of organizations which are commercial in nature or which present safety hazards to the
general public.
(4)
The regulations contained in this article are not intended to restrict the rights of newspaper vendors and do not
apply to newspaper vendors.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Sec. 14-92. - Definitions.
Charitable organization. As used herein shall mean a group which is or holds itself out to be benevolent,
educational, voluntary help, philanthropic, humane, patriotic, religious or eleemosynary organization, or any
person who solicits or obtains contributions solicited from the public for charitable purposes. "Charitable
organization" shall not be deemed to include a duly constituted religious organization or any group affiliated
with and forming an integral part of that organization.
Person means any individual, organization, trust, foundation, group, association, entity, partnership, corporation,
society, or any combination of them.
Solicitors or peddlers shall include any person requesting, directly or indirectly, money, property, financial
assistance, or any other thing of value on the plea or representation that such money, property, financial
assistance, or other thing of value or a portion of it will be used for a charitable purpose or will benefit a
charitable organization. "Solicitors" or "peddlers" shall include any person, whether resident of the city or not,
travelling either by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance from place to place, or
from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, and personal property of
any nature, offering and exposing the same for sale, or taking or attempting to take orders for sales or making
sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who, without travelling from place to place, shall sell or offer the
same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, or other vehicle or conveyance or from any public place, and
further provided that one who solicits orders or attempts to solicit orders and as a separate transaction makes
deliveries or promises to make deliveries to purchasers in the future as part of a scheme or design to evade the
provisions of this chapter is deemed to be a "solicitor" or "peddler." "Solicitors" or "peddlers" shall include the
words "hawkers," "hucksters," "canvassers," "itinerant merchant," "itinerant vendors" and "solicitors for
donations." "Solicitors" or "peddlers" shall not include newspaper vendors.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
494/653
Sec. 14-93. - Charitable solicitation requirements.
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to solicit for charitable organizations as hereinabove
defined unless the charitable organization is located within the corporate limits of the city, or, unless the
organization is registered and has a permit from the department of state under the provisions of F.S. ch. 496.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Sec. 14-94. - Solicitor or peddler to have a permit.
(a)
It shall be unlawful for any solicitor or peddler to solicit, as defined in this chapter, for any commercial or
charitable purpose within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a permit therefor in compliance
with the provisions of this chapter and other applicable ordinances. No person under the age of eighteen (18)
may obtain a permit or engage in solicitation activities in any manner.
(b)
No permit issued under this chapter shall be transferable.
(c)
All permits issued under this chapter shall automatically expire 90 days after the date of issuance thereof, unless
a specific length of time of operation is designated in the permit.
(d)
The granting of a permit by the city shall not create any agency relationship nor any employer/employee
relationship with the permittee.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Sec. 14-95. - Application procedure.
(a)
Applicants for a permit under this chapter as a solicitor or peddler must file with the city, a sworn application in
writing signed by the applicant if an individual, or by all partners if a partnership, or by the president if a
corporation. The applicant shall provide the following information:
(1)
Name and description of the applicant;
(2)
a.
Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant; and the address of applicant for past five (5)
years;
b.
The name of the individual having management authority or supervision of the applicant's business during the
time that it is proposed to be conducted in the city;
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
495/653
c.
The capacity in which the applicant will act;
(3)
The name and address of the person, if any, for whose purpose the business will be conducted, and, if a
corporation, the state of incorporation;
(4)
A brief description of the nature, character and quality of the business and the goods or services to be offered for
sale or delivery;
(5)
If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship;
(6)
The length of time for which the right to do business is desired;
(7)
The nature of the advertising proposed to be done for the business;
(8)
If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with permit number or other means of
identification;
(9)
A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of filing of the
application, which shall be at least two (2) inches by two (2) inches, showing the head and shoulders of the
applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner, and fingerprints of the applicant;
(10)
Proof of insurance coverage for a public liability and property damage insurance policy or commitment with a
company authorized to transact business in the state to secure payment of any loss or damage resulting from any
accident arising out of or caused by the operation of said solicitor or peddler. Failure to maintain appropriate
insurance coverage shall be deemed sufficient grounds for revocation of the permit as set forth in section 14-98;
(11)
Signed agreement to hold harmless the city and its officers, agents, and employees; and
(12)
Authorization for release of information and for conducting a criminal records background check in connection
with the investigation of the application pursuant to section 14-96 herein.
(b)
At the time of filing the application, a nonrefundable fee of two-hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be paid to
the city to cover the cost of investigation of the facts stated therein.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
496/653
(c)
No individual under the age of eighteen (18) shall be qualified to apply for a permit or to conduct or take part in
any activities under this chapter as a solicitor or peddler.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Sec. 14-96. - Investigation of applicant.
(a)
Upon receipt of the application provided for in section 14-95, the city shall refer the original to the chief of
police who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral turpitude to be made as he deems
necessary for the protection of the public health, safety, morals or general welfare.
(b)
If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be
unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on such application his disapproval and his reasons for the same,
and return to the city, who shall notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit will be
issued.
(c)
If as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be
satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval, and return the application to the
city, who shall notify the applicant that a permit for solicitor or peddler shall be issued upon payment of the
prescribed applicable permit fees.
(d)
The application process from the time of the initial investigation until the time of approval or denial shall be
completed within forty-five (45) days.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Sec. 14-97. - Exhibition of permit identification card.
Each individual solicitor must prominently display a permit identification card issued by the city on their outer
clothing in a manner which is clearly visible. This permit identification card shall contain a certified copy of the
permit, the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name, address and photograph of the
permittee, the class of permit, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as
the permit number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in such peddling or soliciting. Permit
identification cards shall be obtained from the city at a cost of twenty dollars ($20.00) per card. The city shall
keep a permanent record of all permit identification cards issued. Solicitors and peddlers are required to produce
their permit identification card for examination at the request of any citizen or officer. Failure to prominently
display a permit identification card shall be deemed a violation of this section punishable under section 14-103.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Sec. 14-98. - Revocation of permit.
(a)
Permits issued under the provision of this chapter may be revoked by the code board after notice and a hearing.
Notice of hearing for revocation shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
497/653
and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed to the permittee at his last known address, at
least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the hearing.
(b)
A permit granted under this chapter may be revoked for any of the following causes:
(1)
Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for permit;
(2)
Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business as solicitor or peddler;
(3)
Any violation of this chapter;
(4)
Conviction of any crime involving moral turpitude;
(5)
Conducting the business of soliciting or peddling in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a
breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the public.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Sec. 14-99. - Permissible hours for solicitation.
It shall be unlawful to solicit or peddle in any manner for commercial or charitable organizations between the
hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. within the corporate limits of the city.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Sec. 14-100. - Use of streets.
(a)
No solicitor or peddler shall operate within one thousand (1,000) feet of the property line of a school, publicoperated
park or recreational facility within the city.
(b)
No solicitor or peddler shall have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets, alleys, or other public
places, nor shall any be permitted a stationery location, nor shall he be permitted to operate in such a way as
would restrict or interfere with the ingress or egress of an abutting property owner or tenant, or create or become
a public nuisance, increase traffic congestion or delay, or constitute a hazard to traffic, life or property, or create
an obstruction to adequate access for fire, police or sanitation vehicles. No person shall obstruct the free,
convenient, and normal use of any public street, highway, or road impeding, hindering, stifling, retarding,
restraining traffic or passage thereon, by standing or approaching motor vehicles thereon, or by endangering the
safe movement of vehicles or pedestrians travelling thereon. The judgment of a police officer or code
enforcement officer exercised in good faith shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the soliciting or peddling
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
498/653
activity constitutes a traffic or pedestrian impediment or hazard or access obstruction. Penalties for a violation of
this section shall be as contained in section 7½-3.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99; Ord. No. 09O-11-165, § 5, 12-14-09)
Sec. 14-101. - Appeals.
(a)
Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief of police or the city in the denial of an application for a permit,
as provided in section 14-96, or in the decision to revoke a permit, as provided in section 14-98, shall have the
right to appeal to the city commission.
(b)
Such appeal shall be taken by filing a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal with the
city clerk within fourteen (14) days after the decision by the code board has been made.
(c)
The city shall set a time and place for the hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the
appellant in the same manner as provided in section 14-98 for notice of hearing on revocation. The decision and
order of the city commission on such appeal shall be final and conclusive.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Sec. 14-101.1. - Right-of-way solicitors, peddlers, or canvassers.
(a)
Definitions . For the purposes of this section the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly
indicates or requires a different meaning. Right-of-way solicitors, peddlers and canvassers continue to remain
subject to all of the provisions contained in Article VI of this chapter, however this section shall take precedence
where any conflict is noted specifically as to right-of-way solicitors, peddlers, or canvassers.
Right-of-way solicitor, peddler, or canvasser . Any person who sells or offers for sale any thing or service of any
kind, or who seeks any donation of any kind, or who personally hands to or seeks to transmit by hand or receive
by hand any thing or service of any kind, whether or not payment in exchange is required or requested, to any
person who operates or occupies a motor vehicle of any kind, which vehicle is engaged in travel on or within
any portion of any of the streets or roadways in the city, whether or not such vehicle is temporarily stopped in
the travel lanes of the road. The term shall not apply to any person who merely holds or displays a sign lawfully
permitted to be displayed by a person as long as there is no entry by such person or sign into any portion of the
roadway or its median. Further, this term shall not apply to official citations or notices provided pursuant to
governmental authority.
(b)
Prohibition of right-of-way solicitors, peddlers, and canvassers .
Findings; purpose; intent .
(1)
The city commission desires to adopt an ordinance restricting right-of-way solicitors, peddlers, and canvassers to
certain streets and roadways located in the city because such solicitors, peddlers, and canvassers pose a danger to
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
499/653
themselves and the public at large by interfering with the safe movement of normal vehicular traffic which
constitutes a traffic or pedestrian impediment or hazard or access obstruction;
(2)
According to the Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles 2007 Florida Traffic Crash
Statistics Report, five hundred fifty (550) pedestrians were killed on Florida roadways in 2007; sixty-five (65) of
those pedestrians were killed on roadways in Broward County; and
(3)
Based upon statistics collected by the Surface Transportation Policy Project, the Miami-Fort Lauderdale area is
one of the most dangerous areas in the United States for pedestrians; and
(4)
The city has experienced pedestrian crashes resulting from solicitation in the roadways;
(5)
Numerous types of right-of-way solicitors, peddlers, and canvassers and may seek to operate within the city,
including, but not limited to, children, adolescents and adults who seek to collect money for school and
community activities; vendors who sell flowers, newspapers and other products; and people who seek donations
or distribute written information; and
(6)
Right-of-way solicitors, peddlers, and canvassers approach motorists and passengers in motor vehicles engaged
in travel on roads, and are particularly susceptible and vulnerable to serious injury, or death due to the speed and
number of motorists who operate vehicles on busy roads within the city; and
(7)
Roads are primarily designed for vehicular traffic and are not suited to safely accommodate right-of-way
solicitors, peddlers, and canvassers; and
(8)
According to a local newspaper article published in 2005, 29 right-of-way solicitors, peddlers, and/or canvassers
have been seriously injured and at least 14 more have been killed by motor vehicles during a 15-year period;
many of those deaths occurred while the solicitor, peddler, and/or canvasser was sitting or standing in a median
or on the side of the street (including a Sun-Sentinel newspaper vendor who was struck by a car while carrying
papers on U.S. 1 and Broward Boulevard in Fort Lauderdale on July 50, 2000; a Miami Herald newspaper
vendor who was standing on the median at Federal Highway and Stirling Road on May 25, 2002; and a Miami
Herald newspaper vendor who was selling papers on the side of the street at Stirling Road and U.S. 441 on
August 7, 2002); and
(9)
The presence of right-of-way solicitors, peddlers, and canvassers and interferes with the safe movement of
normal vehicular traffic and causes an unnecessary traffic safety hazard; and
(10)
The road network in the city is substantially burdened by a high volume of traffic, and road design frequently
includes complex vehicle turn movements that demand a driver's strict attention; and
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
500/653
(11)
It is the intention of the city commission to use the least restrictive means to advance the significant
governmental interests of traffic safety and public safety and, consequently, the city staff analyzed each of the
major roads within the city and determined that the roads listed in subsection (c) below present an increased and
significant danger for use by distracted drivers, pedestrians and right-of-way solicitors, peddlers, and canvassers
and pose the greatest threat to traffic and public safety in reference to activities and use by right-of-way
solicitors, peddlers, and canvassers, and therefore the city commission has determined that such activities and
use by right-of way solicitors, peddlers, and canvassers shall be prohibited on the roadways listed in subsection
(c) below; and
(12)
It is the finding of the city commission that many other alternative channels of communication (other than rightof-
way solicitation, peddling, and canvassing on the prohibited roadways) exist for persons who seek to exercise
their First Amendment freedoms, such as, but by no means limited to, solicitation of funds or distribution of
literature through the mail or at alternate locations (such as houses of worship, shopping areas and special
events); the sale and/or distribution of newspapers through home or office delivery, vending machines and retail
stores; and the sale of goods and services at retail stores, through the internet and from vending machines; and
(15)
The city commission desires to preserve and protect the personal safety and quality of life of its residents and of
those who use streets within the city, both pedestrians and motorists alike; and
(14)
The city commission has reviewed the proposed regulations provided by this section and finds that such
regulations accomplish the purposes intended while utilizing the least restrictive means to further and protect the
health and safety of its residents and those who use the city's designated roadways; and
(15)
The city commission finds that it is in the best interests of the residents of the city to adopt this section.
(c)
Prohibited roadways . It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a right-of-way solicitor, peddler, or canvasser:
(i) anywhere on or at any intersection along University Drive; and also (ii) within two hundred (200) feet from
the lateral curb or boundary line of the following specific intersections within the city boundaries of the city:
(1)
Oakland Park Boulevard and Rock Island Road.
(2)
Oakland Park Boulevard and Inverrary Boulevard/N.W. 56 th Avenue.
(3)
Sunrise Boulevard and N.W. 31 st Avenue.
(4)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
501/653
State Road 7 (U.S. 441) and 12 th Street.
(5)
State Road 7 (U.S. 441) and 16 th Street.
(6)
State Road 7 (U.S. 441) and 19 th Street.
(d)
Enforcement and penalties . The enforcement of this section shall not, in any way, preclude the enforcement of
Florida Statutes, Section 316.130(5), as applicable.
(1)
It shall be the duty of any police officer or code enforcement officer of the city to require any person seen
soliciting, peddling or canvassing and who is not known by the officer to be duly permitted, to produce his
solicitor's, peddler's, or canvasser's permit, and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found
in violation of this section, Article VI, or any part of this chapter.
(2)
Any person who violates any terms or provisions of this section, any part of article VI, or this chapter shall be
subject to penalties as contained in section 7½-3. Violators may be issued a uniform Code citation or a notice to
appear for such violations which may be prosecuted before a court of competent jurisdiction and, upon
conviction of such violation before the judge of the county court, shall be subject to the penalties ordered by the
court judge. Each day of the violation of any term or provision of this section, any part of article VI or this
chapter shall constitute a separate and distinct violation.
(Ord. No. 13O-12-159, § 1, 1-13-14)
Sec. 14-102. - Enforcement.
It shall be the duty of any police officer or code enforcement officer of the city to require any person seen
soliciting or peddling and who is not know by the officer to be duly permitted, to produce his solicitor's or
peddler's permit, and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be in violation thereof.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Sec. 14-103. - Penalty.
Any person convicted of violating any portion of this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalties as set
forth in section 7½-3. Each day any violation shall continue to exist shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99; Ord. No. 13O-12-159, § 1, 1-13-14)
Secs. 14-104—14-109. - Reserved.
DIVISION 2. - SOLICITATION BY MINORS
Sec. 14-110. - Solicitation by minors.
(a)
Definitions. [The following terms, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed herein:]
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
502/653
Minor means any natural person who has not attained the age of eighteen (18) years.
Rights-of-way means land dedicated, deeded, used, or to be used for a street, alley, walkway, boulevard,
drainage facility, access or ingress and egress by the public, certain designated individuals or governing bodies.
Soliciting means and includes any one (1) or more of the following activities:
(1)
Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind,
character or description whatever for any kind of consideration whatever;
(2)
Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or
publication;
(3)
Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of
publication; or
(4)
Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit
of any charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project.
(b)
Prohibited.
(1)
It is hereby deemed unlawful for any minor person to go upon the public rights-of-way of the city for the
purpose of soliciting.
(2)
It is hereby deemed unlawful for any parent, guardian, custodian, corporation, or any other form of business
entity to request, supervise or direct a minor to go upon the public rights-of-way for the purpose of soliciting.
(c)
Penalty. Any violator of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not
less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
(Ord. No. 99O-1-106, § 1, 2-8-99; Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Secs. 14-111—14-115. - Reserved.
DIVISION 3. - DOOR-TO-DOOR SOLICITATION
Sec. 14-116. - Uninvited solicitation.
(a)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
503/653
Intent and purpose. The city council wishes to protect the privacy of residents who do not desire door-to-door
solicitation or canvassing and to protect the privacy of those residents who wish to receive door-to-door
solicitation or canvassing only during certain desired hours. In addition, it is the intent and purpose of the city
council to protect and further the rights of residents who desire to receive door-to-door solicitation or canvassing
at all times.
(b)
Definitions. Soliciting shall mean and include any one (1) or more of the following activities:
(1)
Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind,
character or description whatever for any kind of consideration whatever; or
(2)
Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or
publication; or
(3)
Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of
publication; or
(4)
Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit
of any charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project.
(c)
Duty of solicitor. It shall be the duty of every solicitor or canvasser, commercial or noncommercial, upon going
onto any premises in the city on which a residence is located to proceed from the adjacent road right-of-way
directly toward the front or main entrance of such residence to examine and look for the notice provided for in
paragraph (d) herein. If any such notice is posted, then any solicitor or canvasser shall immediately and
peacefully depart from the premises and shall leave on the premises no documents or literature of any kind.
Under no circumstances shall a solicitor enter upon a side or rear yard of any residence unless expressly invited
to do so by the occupant thereof.
Any solicitor or canvasser who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately
and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by an occupant or owner thereof.
(d)
Declaration. It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a trespass for any person to:
(1)
Go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door or create any sound in any manner calculated
to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence for the purpose of securing an audience with the
occupant thereof and engaged in soliciting or canvassing commercially or noncommercially in defiance of the
notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of this section.
(2)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
504/653
Not immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by an occupant or owner
thereof.
(e)
Notice to solicitor.
(1)
When a residence owner or occupant does not wish to receive door-to-door solicitation or canvassing, a sign
shall be posted in the immediate vicinity of the front door or front door bell area, which sign shall read:
NO SOLICITATION INVITED
or
NO SOLICITING
(2)
The signs provided for in subparagraph (1) shall be made of a durable material, such as plastic, metal or wood.
Further, the sign letters shall be at least three-quarter inch in height. In addition, the sign shall be capable of
being temporarily or permanently affixed to the hanging surface.
(3)
Penalties. Any person, corporation or business entity violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon
conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
(Ord. No. 90-138, § 1, 7-16-90; Ord. No. 99O-8-138, § 1, 9-13-99)
Secs. 14-117—14-119. - Reserved.
ARTICLE VII. - SEXUAL OFFENDERS AND SEXUAL PREDATORS
Sec. 14-120. - Sexual offenders and sexual predators implementation definitions and conditions pursuant to
Florida Statutes, 775.21, 794.065 (transferred and renumbered as 775.215), 947.1405, and 948.30.
In order to fully implement and enforce the intent of Florida Statutes 775.21, 794.065 (transferred and
renumbered as 775.215), 947.1405 and 948.30, the aforementioned sections of the Florida Statutes are hereby
adopted as a part of this article and incorporated into the City of Lauderhill Code of Ordinances subject to the
following definitions and conditions for the application and enforcement of these sections:
(1)
Definitions for application of provisions within Florida Statutes 775.21, 794.065 (transferred and renumbered as
775.215) and 947.1405:
Apartment building complex, condominium or homeowner association common areas for use by its residents
means a pool area, sports field or court, clubhouse, picnic or garden area, which is not within a structure where
its residents reside.
Child care facility means shall have the same meaning provided in 402.302 which provides that "child care
facility" includes any child care center or child care arrangement which provides child care for more than five
(5) children unrelated to the operator and which receives a payment, fee, or grant for any of the children
receiving care, wherever operated, and whether or not operated for profit. The following are not included:
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
505/653
a.
Public schools and nonpublic schools and their integral programs, except as provided in 402.3025;
b.
Summer camps having children in full-time residence;
c.
Summer day camps;
d.
Bible schools normally conducted during vacation periods; and
e.
Operators of transient establishments, as defined in chapter 509, which provide child care services solely for the
guests of their establishment or resort, provided that all child care personnel of the establishment are screened
according to the level 2 screening requirements of chapter 435.
Day care center means all facilities licensed, privately accredited, or designated by a governmental agency, to
care for minors when not in school, or adults during the day.
Park means all public and private geographical locations designated for the purpose of providing recreational
activity and where children regularly congregate. The location need not be within the physical confines of the
city limits of the City of Lauderhill if it is within one thousand (1,000) feet of the city limits of the City of
Lauderhill. The property need not be completed to be designated as a park, if the property, including a
freestanding community center (containing recreational activity), is under development (minimally the property
has been purchased or obtained, and preliminary site plans or site design, has been filed with a governmental
agency).
Playground means a designated independent area in the community or neighborhood that is designed primarily
for children and has one (1) or more play structures.
Recreational activity means a type of permanent activity intended for the enjoyment of the general public, or for
use by multiple families within an apartment building complex, condominium association or homeowner
association. Such activity may be active (providing competitive activity, i.e., including, but not limited to,
football, baseball, tennis, basketball, golf, card playing, etc.) or passive (providing no competitive activity, i.e.,
exercising, general swimming, fishing, boating, weight lifting, etc.), on land or on water, indoors or outdoor, for
a fee or free, and on private or public property, including activity within an apartment building complex,
condominium or homeowner association common areas for use by its residents.
Recreational areas within an apartment building complex, condominium and homeowner associations means
common areas in such associations, for use by its residents as a pool area, sports field or court, clubhouse, picnic
or garden area, which is not within a structure where its residents reside.
School includes all public and private schools, including all primary, secondary, post-secondary, technical,
vocational, religious, college, and charter schools, where the intent is upon completion of studies, that the
student receives a diploma, degree, certification, or official recognition to enable the student to perform a
specific task they could not have previously without such training, including all land attached thereto, which
may also be defined to be a park, but does not include facilities dedicated exclusively to the education of adults.
Within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of any school, child care center, day care center, park or
playground means the measurement of which shall be the shortest distance on a straight line from the property
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
506/653
line of each of the properties being measured.
Because of the declared compelling and important state and local interests in the health, safety and welfare of the
general public, as more fully provided for in Florida Statutes 775.21, 794.065 (transferred and renumbered as
775.215, 947.1405 and 948.30, and herein, the definitions contained herein shall be liberally construed in favor
of declaring properties as schools, parks, child care centers, and day care centers, playgrounds, or areas where
children congregate. The foregoing definitions shall only apply to this article.
a.
It is hereby specifically provided that references to "day care center, child care center, park, playground or areas
where children congregate" shall be defined to include, but not necessarily be limited to, the following properties
for the purposes of enforcement of this section/chapter:
1.
All designated parks owned by any governmental agency (including parks outside of the City of Lauderhill city
boundaries), and playgrounds, including, but not limited to the following parks which are commonly known as:
Veterans Park, Westwind Park, Jackie Gleason Park, Waterford Park, Ruth Rothkopf Park, Blvd. Woods Park,
Ilene Lieberman Botanical Gardens, Lauderhill Sports Park, the Original City Hall Park, John E. Mullins Park,
Ettinger Park, Gateway Park, Wolk Park, Sadkin Community Center, Central Broward Regional Park,
Meditation Park, Renaissance Park, 31st Avenue Park, 17th Street Park, Inverrary Lake, Mae Jenkins Park, St.
George Park, Tamarac Community Center, Windemere Community Center, West Ken Lark Park, and any
additional parks that may be added to the city park inventory (said names may be their commonly known names
and not their proper name);
2.
All private parks, including, but not limited to: Forest Lakes Estates Park(s), Meditation Park, the Inverrary
Waterfall, the open space area within the circular driveway of the Falls of Inverrary, the Swap Shop Amusement
Park, the Forest Trace Recreational Center, the JAFCO Group Home playground, and all playgrounds attached
to houses of religious worship;
3.
All golf courses, including, the Inverrary Country Club and Golf Course (East, West and South), Lauderhill
Municipal Golf Course and Golfing Center, and the Woodlands Country Club and Golf Course, if a children's
program is conducted at such site, including but not limited to the First Tee Program;
4.
All nature preserves which were required to be established by the City of Lauderhill, Broward County or the
State of Florida; and
5.
All recreational areas within an apartment building complex, condominium and homeowner association.
b.
It is hereby specifically provided that the following properties are not defined as parks, notwithstanding any
other provision to the contrary:
1.
Private swimming pools, playgrounds, or other recreational facilities at for single-family homes; and

2.
All commercially zoned property, where activity is conducted for profit, except for golf courses and their
attached country club facilities, and amusement parks; and
3.

(2)
Conditions:
a.
The city manager is directed to compile a list describing all properties within the City of Lauderhill (including
areas designated to become part of the City of Lauderhill) and within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of
the city limits of the City of Lauderhill, which would be declared to be parks, schools, child care centers, and
day care centers pursuant to the definitions provided herein and create a map of such properties, indicating the
areas to which Florida Statutes 794.065 (transferred and renumbered as 775.215, 947.1405, and 948.30 would be
applicable, within thirty (30) days of passage of this article.
b.
Thereafter, the city manager is directed, within an additional thirty (30) days, to compile a list of and indicate the
location on the map, sexual predators and sexual offenders within the borders of the City of Lauderhill,
including areas designated to become part of the City of Lauderhill, within the meaning of Florida Statutes, from
the information provided by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement.
(Ord. No. 05O-08-168, § 1, 9-12-05; Ord. No. 10O-12-174, § 1, 1-10-2011)
Sec. 14-121. - Penalties, remedies.
(a)
Any sexual predators or sexual offenders found to be in violation of Florida Statutes 794.065 (transferred and
renumbered as 775.215), 947.1405 or 948.30 are to be reported to the appropriate governmental agency, and the
city manager is authorized to take all legal action necessary to enforce the terms of this article and the applicable
Florida Statutes. The city manager is directed to update such lists and maps regularly as necessary. Each list and
map prepared shall be made available to the city commission and the public for regular inspection.
(b)
A person who violates this article or the applicable Florida Statutes adopted herein, shall be punished by a fine
not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by
both such fine and imprisonment. For a second or subsequent conviction of a violation of this section or the
corresponding Florida Statutes, such person shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) or by imprisonment for up to twelve (12) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. In
addition to these fines, the city shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief and such other relief permitted by law to
preclude, prevent, terminate, cease or obviate any such violation of this article or the applicable Florida Statutes
adopted herein.
(Ord. No. 05O-08-168, § 2, 9-12-05; Ord. No. 10O-12-174, § 2, 1-10-2011)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 15-1. - Hours of operation; night-time exception.
All city parks which do not have lighting for events may be open to all persons from sunrise and shall close at
sunset. All city parks which do have lighting for night-time events may be open to all persons from sunrise and
may remain open after sunset, with closing times to be determined by the city administration.
(Ord. No. 78-112, § 1, 6-13-78; Ord. No. 91-149, § 1, 8-26-91)
Sec. 15-2. - Unlawful use.
It shall be unlawful for any person to use or be physically present upon property designated as a city park
beyond the hours of operation set forth in this chapter.
(Ord. No. 79-106, § 1, 3-13-79)
Sec. 15-3. - Penalties for article violation.
Any person found guilty of violating any section of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of up to five hundred
dollars ($500.00) per violation or may be imprisoned up to thirty (30) days or, in the discretion of the court, may
be both fined and imprisoned.
(Ord. No. 79-106, § 1, 3-13-79)
Sec. 15-4. - Fees charged to city employees.
Each [All] employees of the city shall be considered as residents of the city, regardless of the city wherein they
reside, for purposes of fees charged for use of city recreational facilities.
(Ord. No. 91-169, § 1, 9-11-91)
Sec. 15-5. - Fees charged to residents of unincorporated areas in the process of being annexed into the city.
All residents of those unincorporated areas which are in the process of being annexed into the city shall be
considered as residents of the city for the purposes of fees charged for the use of city recreational facilities as
soon as all final procedures and approvals of the annexation process have been concluded, regardless of the
actual effective date of the annexation.
(Ord. No. 05O-03-130, § 1, 4-11-05)
Secs. 15-6—15-30. - Reserved.

Sec. 15-31. - Definitions.
Certain terms as used in this article are herein defined as follows:
Golf facilities shall mean all real property designated for use as a golf course within the city along with all
necessary personal property (e.g., golf carts, fertilizer, lawn seed, mowing equipment, sprinkler systems) that
may be needed in the ordinary operation of a golf course.
General revenues shall mean all user charges, admission fees, membership dues and concession stand proceeds
derived from the operation of the city's golf facilities.
Ordinary expenses shall mean the cost of upkeep and maintenance of all golf facilities, including, but not limited
to, all labor and material needed for the continued operation of said facilities.
(Ord. No. 81-127, § 1, 5-26-81)

A golf fund for the purpose of operating all of the city's golf facilities is herein created. Said fund shall receive
all general revenues from the operation of the city's golf facilities and also shall be used for the paying of all
ordinary expenses for the continued operation and maintenance of all the city's golf facilities.
(Ord. No. 81-127, § 2, 5-26-81)

For groups of more than 15 persons, a special permit is required
(b)
[Rules and regulations.] The city recreational department shall, from time to time, create rules and regulations
for the use of city athletic fields and municipal facilities. These rules and regulations shall be created and
amended from time to time by the city recreation department and may be enforced by that department to the
exclusion or expulsion of violators or by the withdrawal of permits solely at the discretion of the recreation
department. In the event that a permit shall be withdrawn, any fees previously paid to the city shall not be
refunded in whole or in part.
(c)
Use by commercial and/or for-profit users.
(1)
Intent and purpose. The city commission wishes to continue its efforts to protect and preserve its parks and
recreation facilities as areas devoted to rest, relaxation, recreational sports, family outings, special events and
other activities which serve to enhance the enjoyment of life, for the use of its present and future citizens. The
city commission is aware, however, that the personal liberties guaranteed under the First Amendment of the
United States Constitution allow persons the right to express their fundamental freedoms of speech, assembly
and religion in public areas such as the city parks, since parks have been consistently regarded and treated by the
courts as traditional public forums for such expressions.
It is, therefore, the purpose and intent of the city commission to try to strike a reasonable balance and achieve a
reconciliation of such uses, which occasionally compete with each other, by the enactment of regulations which
are content neutral as to the subject matter of expressions of opinions or of the viewpoints of a person or a
group. Furthermore, the city commission wishes to ensure that such regulations are tailored to avoid undue
restrictions upon or intrusions into personal freedoms of expression and to further ensure that reasonable
alternative modes of communications are available.
In addition, the city commission is aware that use of the parks and recreation facilities by commercial and forprofit
users may result in damage to the parks and recreation facilities greater than that customarily associated
with park usage. The city commission wishes to protect the condition of its parks and recreation facilities so that
the city's residents are not unfairly and unduly burdened with bearing the costs to repair said damages.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
514/653
(2)
[Reservation required, when.] Any person, organization, entity or group of persons who wishes to temporarily
and exclusively use any city park area, recreation facility, or both, to sponsor, conduct or stage any function,
activity or event to be conducted or held with the recreation area, facility or both, must obtain a reservation in
advance of the event from the city parks and recreation department on a form promulgated by that department
for such purpose.
a.
Reservation procedure. Upon application, a reservation for any such use shall be issued to the applicant in
writing, specifying:
1.
The date and time it was issued;
2.
The name, address and telephone number of the applicant or designated agent;
3.
The name or other identification of the proposed event or use, including a brief description of it;
4.
The requested hours and days of use; and
5.
The boundaries, location or identity of the recreation area, facility, or all of the foregoing sought to be used.
(3)
All such applications shall be processed free of charge on an annual "first-come, first-served" basis,
commencing at the beginning of each calendar year. However, the actual reservation of the recreation services,
recreation areas, recreation facilities, park area or any of the foregoing shall be subject to payment to the city of
the user fees as established by the city.
(4)
Each reservation shall be issued promptly by the department as soon as a determination has been made that:
a.
There will be no overlapping, conflicting or concurrent use of an area, facility or both;
b.
The area, facility or both are otherwise reasonably available for use (for example, some areas cannot be
continuously used without damage; instead, the area must "rest and recover" from use to regenerate grass, and be
maintained so as to keep in good condition);
c.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
515/653
City equipment or personnel which must reasonably be available to service the reservation are so available (e.g.,
stages or special duty police or recreation personnel); and
d.
All other requirements of this section are satisfied or the city has received reasonable assurances that same will
be satisfied.
(5)
If the proposed function, activity, or event is, or may be, in the reasonable estimation of both the police chief and
the parks and recreation director, likely to be attended by a large number of patrons, attendees or invitees, they
shall, after consultation with the fire department and the applicant, outline reasonable conditions governing
vehicular parking locations and traffic control, points of access for pedestrians, movement of pedestrian traffic
within the park area, the facility or both, and provisions to ensure that the grounds are within the park area, the
facility or both, and provisions to ensure that the grounds are protected from undue wear and tear, damage or
destruction. For all purposes of this section, the term "director" shall include the director of the parks and leisure
services department or any authorized designee of the director. Further, the director shall ensure that suitable
arrangements are made in consultation with the applicant for sanitation and hygiene, such that a reasonable
number of restroom facilities are accessible (or, if necessary, additional temporary facilities are procured by the
applicant), and that trash collection and disposal arrangements are sufficient to accommodate the event. The
"reasonable estimation" by the director and police chief of the anticipated number of patrons shall be based upon
consideration of the following factors:
a.
Prior experiences with activities conducted by the particular applicant for the function, activity or event
requested, or prior experience with similar functions, events or comparable activities;
b.
The size of the entire park, including pedestrian and vehicular access in relation to the area facility or both
sought to be used; and
c.
The anticipated size or intensity and characteristics of the proposed use.
(6)
If the application involves allocation of limited space for exhibitors, concessionaires and other event
participants, and there are corresponding limitations on the areas remaining for pedestrian traffic, then any and
all persons who wish to exhibit, sell or distribute any items of any kind may be required by the sponsor of the
event to do so within the confines of designated booths or areas, to ensure orderly movement and maintenance of
crowd control.
(7)
Deposits; insurance.
a.
The director shall require the posting of a damage deposit in the minimum amount of five hundred dollars
($500.00). If the expected number of patrons, attendees or invitees is reasonably expected to exceed five
hundred (500) persons, then the amount of such deposit shall be increased by one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each additional five hundred (500) persons anticipated to attend. Such deposit may be used by the city to defray
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
516/653
the costs to repair any damages to park and/or recreation facilities that arise as a result of the function, activity or
event. Any balance remaining, or the entire deposit, if applicable, shall be returned to the applicant within fifteen
(15) days after the function, activity or event has concluded. Any person who is dissatisfied with the
determination of the city to retain all or a portion of the deposit may appeal such determination to the city
commission for a hearing. Such appeal must be made with fifteen (15) days from the date the applicant is
notified of the determination of the city.
b.
If an event is authorized to provide for sales of beer, wine or both, as otherwise provided in this section, the
applicable deposit shall be doubled.
c.
Each applicant shall provide the city a certificate of insurance with such limits, coverages and underwriters as
the city risk insurance supervisor may require, given the size, nature, and scope of the activity contemplated by
the reservation. The city shall be named as an "additional insured" under the policy of insurance and a copy of
said insurance page shall be provided to the city prior to the date of the event.
(8)
On those occasions in which a park reservation is sought, an applicant whose purpose is primarily devoted to
civic, charitable, religious, or fraternal purposes may be authorized by the department to provide for the sale and
consumption of beer, wine, or both during the function, activity or event, provided, however, that if the city
police department determines, at any time while the event is underway, that such activities should be terminated,
such determination shall be immediately communicated to and observed by the applicant. Any applicant
obtaining such authorization shall be solely responsible for securing all applicable state licenses relating to such
sales and consumption.
(9)
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person to exhibit, sell or offer for sale any item or
thing, to distribute literature of any kind, or to convey any message, opinion or the like within the park area,
facility or both which is the subject of a reservation unless such person has obtained authorization of the holder
of the reservation.
(Ord. No. 86-130, § 1, 7-28-86; Ord. No. 86-136, § 1, 8-25-86; Ord. No. 87-153, § 1, 10-26-87; Ord. No. 88-
160, § 1, 10-24-88; Ord. No. 89-169, § 1, 9-25-89; Ord. No. 92-171, §§ 1, 2, 9-14-92; Ord. No. 93-101, § 1, 1-
25-93; Ord. No. 93-123, § 1, 3-29-93; Ord. No. 93-134, § 1, 5-10-93; Ord. No. 94-123, § 2, 6-27-94; Ord. No.
98O-1-101, § 2, 1-26-98; Ord. No. 00O-3-17, § 1, 4-10-00; Ord. No. 02O-4-125, § 1, 5-13-02; Ord. No. 04O-01-
109, § 1, 2-9-04; Ord. No. 04O-08-163, § 1, 9-13-04; Ord. No. 05O-09-184, § 1, 9-26-05; Ord. No. 07O-06-136,
§ 2, 11-26-07; Ord. No. 12O-08-132, §§ 1, 2(Exh. A), 3, 9-12-2012; Ord. No. 14O-04-114, § 1, 5-12-2014; Ord.

Sec. 15-36. - Drowning awareness safety program.
The city shall conduct a drowning awareness safety program for children of city residents or children attending
city schools, the fee for which shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per participating child.
(Ord. No. 94-118, § 1, 6-13-94)
Chapter 17 - POLICE
Footnotes:

Editor's note— Ordinance No. 94-143, § 1, adopted September 12, 1994, amended Ch. 17 to read as herein set
out. Formerly, ch. 17 consisted of §§ 17-1, 17-2, which pertained to police and derived from Ord. No. 91-130, §
