Sec. 20-23. - Appeal.
Any person wishing to contest a municipal parking violation may do so by filling out the lower portion of the
citation form and returning it to the Broward County Clerk of Courts in the envelope provided. The matter will
then be scheduled for a hearing before a hearing officer. Decisions of the hearing officer are appealable, under
the rules of the court, to the circuit court. Appeals shall be based upon the record of the hearing before the
hearing officer and shall not be hearing de novo. Appellants are responsible for producing the record of the
hearing beyond that which normally results from the civil traffic infraction hearing process.
(Ord. No. 05O-05-151, § 4, 6-13-05)
Editor's note— Ord. No. 05O-05-151, § 4, adopted June 13, 2005, repealed the former § 20-23, and enacted a
new § 20-23 as set out herein. The former § 20-23 pertained to appeal and derived from Ord. No. 05O-04-133, §
3, adopted April 25, 2005.
Sec. 20-24. - Motor vehicles, trailers or other devices capable of being towed, with temporary or permanent
signs affixed thereto, which park in front of buildings on commercial sites.
(a)
This section shall pertain to vans, cars, motor vehicles, trailers, or devices capable of being towed (vehicles)
which are owned or leased by tenants or owners located on the same commercial property.
(b)
Trailers or other devices capable of being towed which have temporary or permanent signs affixed thereto and
motor vehicles with temporary signs affixed thereto are prohibited from commercial sites in the area which
extend between the front or side of the building thereon and any thoroughfare which abuts the commercial site.
(c)
Vehicles which have a bed size which is shorter than six (6) feet long, with permanent signs affixed thereto, and
which are parked in front of a building in a commercial site must be parked in a parking space which
immediately abuts or is closest to their business location.
(d)
Vehicles with a bed size longer than six (6) feet, with permanent signs affixed thereto, may park on commercial
sites in a parking space which immediately abuts, or is closest to, the front of a building from 5:00 p.m. to 9:00
a.m. and on days when the business, which is named on the vehicle, is closed for the entire twenty-four (24)
hour period. In situations where onsite parking in the rear of the building is constrained, such vehicles may park
in clearly-marked reserved spaces directly adjacent to the front of the building from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., but
are otherwise prohibited from parking in the area between the front or side of the building thereon and any
thoroughfare which abuts the commercial site.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
584/653
(e)
Vehicles with permanent signs affixed thereto which are permitted by subsections (c) and (d) to park in front of
buildings on commercial sites must park in front of, or as close as possible to, the business whose name appears
on the vehicle.
(f)
Cars with temporary rooftop signs affixed thereto shall not be subject to the prohibitions of this section if they
are temporarily parked on commercial sites, making pickups or deliveries for purposes of the business which
owns or employs such cars.
(g)
The owner of the business whose name appears on the vehicle, trailer or other device shall be liable for the
violation unless he or she can conclusively prove that he or she is not the owner of such vehicle, trailer or other
device or unless he or she can conclusively prove that his or her business is not located at that commercial site
and that he or she is parked temporarily.
(h)
Any person convicted of violating this section shall be punished as set forth in section 20-19 of this article. Each
day of violation shall constitute a separate violation.

ARTICLE III. - AUTOMATED TRAFFIC INFRACTION DETECTORS
Sec. 20-50. - Short title.
This article shall be known and may be referred to as the "Mark Wandall Traffic Safety Act."
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)
Sec. 20-51. - Purpose.
The purpose of this Act is to authorize the use of unmanned traffic infraction detectors to enforce F.S. §
316.074(1) or 316.075(1)(c)(1) when a driver fails to stop at a red traffic signal on streets and highways under
their jurisdiction pursuant to F.S. § 316.0083. This traffic control signal monitoring system is to promote
compliance with red light signals at intersections and to adopt a civil enforcement system for red light signal
violations. This Act will supplement law enforcement personnel in the enforcement of red light signal violations
and shall not prohibit law enforcement officers from issuing a citation for red light signal violations in
accordance with normal statutory enforcement techniques. Traffic infraction enforcement officers are authorized
to issue a traffic citation under these sections in addition to law enforcement officers.
A notice of violation and traffic citation may not be issued for failure to stop at a red light if the driver is making
a right-hand turn in a careful and prudent manner at an intersection where right-hand turns are permissible.
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
586/653
Sec. 20-52. - Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in
this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Appeal. A contested hearing before the city special master for review of a red light traffic control signal
violation under this article.
Authorized emergency vehicles. Ambulances and vehicles operated by the fire department or law enforcement
agency when responding to an emergency.
Intersection. The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb line; or, if none, then
the lateral boundary lines, of the roadways of two (2) roads which join or intersect one another at, or
approximately at, right angles; or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different roads joining at any
other angle may come in conflict.
Motor vehicle. Any self-propelled vehicle not operated upon rails or guideway, but not including any bicycle,
motorized scooter, electric personal assisted mobility device, or moped.
Notice of violation. A citation issued for a vehicle entering into the intersection against a steady red traffic
control signal.
Owner/vehicle owner. The person or entity identified by the Florida Department of Motor Vehicles, or other
state vehicle registration office, as the registered owner of a vehicle. Such term shall also mean a lessee of a
motor vehicle pursuant to a lease of six (6) months or more.
Record images. Images recorded by a traffic control signal monitoring system/device:
(1)
On:
(a)
Two (2) or more photographs;
(b)
Two (2) or more electronic images;
(c)
Two (2) or more digital images;
(d)
Digital or video movies; or
(e)
Any other medium that can display a violation; and
(2)
Showing the rear of a motor vehicle and on at least one (1) image, clearly identifying the license plate of the
vehicle.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
587/653
Special master. The special master hired by the city.
Traffic control signal. A device exhibiting different colored lights or colored lighted arrows, successively one (1)
at a time or in combination, using only the colors green, yellow, and red which indicate and apply to drivers of
motor vehicles as provided in F.S. § 316.075.
Traffic control signal monitoring system. An electronic system consisting of one (1) or more traffic infraction
detectors.
Traffic infraction enforcement officer. The police officer(s), public safety aide(s), and/or other persons pursuant
to F.S. § 316.640(5), as designated by the chief of police to review recorded images prior to the issuance of a
notice of violation.
Traffic infraction detector. A vehicle sensor installed to work in conjunction with a traffic control signal and a
camera or cameras synchronized to automatically record two (2) or more sequenced photographic or electronic
images or streaming video of only the rear of a motor vehicle at the time the vehicle fails to stop behind the stop
bar or clearly marked stop line when facing a traffic control signal steady red light. Any notification under [F.S.]
§ 316.0083(1)(b) or traffic citation issued by the use of a traffic infraction detector must include a photograph or
other recorded image showing both the license tag of the offending vehicle and the traffic control device being
violated.
Violation (infraction). A traffic offense whereby a traffic control signal monitoring system established that a
vehicle entered an intersection controlled by a duly erected traffic infraction detector at a time when the traffic
control signal for such vehicle's direction of travel was emitting a steady red signal.
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)
Sec. 20-53. - Courtesy warning notice period.
An owner shall receive a courtesy warning notice of violation of this article no less than the first thirty (30) days
after the installation and operation of any traffic control signal monitoring system/device. After the courtesy
warning notice period of no less than thirty (30) days, owners are subject to the enforcement provisions provided
herein. No fines or points shall be assessed during a courtesy warning notice period.
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)
Sec. 20-54. - Notice of violation notification.
Within thirty (30) days after a violation, notification must be sent to the registered owner of the motor vehicle
involved in the violation specifying the remedies available under F.S. § 318.14 and that the violator must pay the
penalty of one hundred fifty-eight dollars ($158.00) to the city finance department, or furnish a notice to appeal
and notarized affidavit within thirty (30) days following the date of the notification of the notice of violation in
order to avoid court fees, costs, and the issuance of a traffic citation.
Contents of notice. A notice issued for any violation of provisions of this article shall contain the following:
(1)
The name and address of the owner of the motor vehicle;
(2)
The license plate and registration number of the motor vehicle;
(3)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
588/653
The make, model and year of the motor vehicle;
(4)
The location of the intersection where the violation occurred;
(5)
The date and time of the violation;
(6)
A statement that the violation stated is pursuant to this article;
(7)
A copy of the recorded images of the violation and notice that the registered owner has the right to review the
photographic or electronic images or the streaming video evidence that constitutes a rebuttable presumption
against the owner of the vehicle. The notice must state the time and place or internet location where the evidence
may be examined and observed;
(8)
The amount of the civil fine, the date by which the civil fine must be paid and procedures for how and where to
pay the civil fine;
(9)
A statement that the recorded images show the violation;
(10)
A statement providing for the procedures and time limit within which to file a notice of appeal to contest the
violation; and
(12)
A statement that if the owner of the violating motor vehicle fails to pay the civil fine within the time allowed, or
fails to timely file a notice to appeal, that the owner shall be deemed to have waived his or her right to contest
the notice of violation and admitted to the violation.
Manner of delivery of notice. The notice of violation shall be sent by first class mail to the address of the owner
of the motor vehicle. If there is more than one (1) registered motor vehicle owner, the notice of violation shall be
sent to all named registered motor vehicle owners. The city, or its designee, shall also have the right, but not the
obligation, to hand deliver the notice of violation upon the motor vehicle owner.
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)
Sec. 20-55. - Owner responsibilities.
(a)
Upon issuance of a notice of violation, the owner shall within thirty (30) days of the date of notification of the
notice of violation either:
(1)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
589/653
Pay the assessed civil fine as stated on the notice of violation; or
(2)
Request an appeal pursuant to the procedure under section 20-56 to contest the notice of violation.
(b)
Any owner who does not comply with subsection (a) within thirty (30) days from the date of the notification of
the notice of violation admits liability and waives the right to contest the notice of violation.
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)
Sec. 20-56. - Notice of appeal/exemptions.
(a)
Upon issuance of a notice of violation the alleged violator may contest the notice by filing a notice of appeal
with the traffic infraction enforcement officer, as provided on the notice of violation, within thirty (30) days
from the date of the notification of the notice of violation. Failure to file the notice of appeal within this time
period shall constitute a waiver of the right to contest the notice of violation and will be considered an admission
of liability.
(b)
The notice of appeal must include a notarized affidavit executed by the registered owner setting forth the
detailed information supporting one (1) of the following permissible grounds for exemption as set out below and
any supporting documents for the appeal. The owner of the motor vehicle involved in the violation is responsible
and liable for paying the uniform traffic citation issued for a violation of [F.S. §] 316.074(1) or 316.075(1)(c)(1)
when the driver failed to stop at a traffic signal, unless the owner can establish that:
1.
The motor vehicle passed through the intersection in order to yield right-of-way to an emergency vehicle or as
part of a funeral procession; or
2.
The motor vehicle passed through the intersection at the direction of a law enforcement officer; or
3.
The motor vehicle was, at the time of the violation, in the care, custody, or control of another person;
a)
An affidavit supporting this exemption must include the name, address, date of birth, and, if known, the driver's
license number of the person who leased, rented, or otherwise had care, custody or control of the motor vehicle
at the time of the alleged violation. If the vehicle was stolen at the time of the offense, the affidavit must include
the police report indicating that the vehicle was stolen; or
4.
A uniform traffic citation was issued by a law enforcement officers to the driver of the motor vehicle for the
alleged violation of [F.S. §] 316.074(1) or 316.075(1)(c)(1); or
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
590/653
5.
Any other reason the trier of fact deems appropriate, including but not limited to evidence of a mother in labor or
a personal health emergency.
(c)
If the violation is not dismissed by the traffic infraction enforcement officer after a review of the notarized
affidavit, the city shall schedule a hearing before the city special master within thirty (30) days of the city's
receipt of the notice of appeal, provided that the notice of appeal is timely filed. The notice of hearing shall be
sent to the owner by certified and first class mail at the address provided on the owner's notice of appeal.
(d)
The traffic infraction enforcement officer shall testify at the special master hearing. The owner, or his attorney or
duly authorized representative, may also present testimony and evidence.
(e)
During a hearing upon any appeal filed pursuant to this section, the recorded images of violation shall be
admissible as evidence of the violation and constitute prima facie evidence Formal rules of evidence shall not
apply at the special master hearing and any relevant evidence may be admitted. Hearsay evidence may be
admitted, but shall not form the sole basis upon which the decision is made. Irrelevant and unduly repetitious
evidence may be excluded. The hearing shall be conducted in a manner to ensure that procedural and substantive
due process is afforded the owner of the violation.
(f)
The special master shall issue a written order either granting or denying the appeal. If the appeal is denied, the
owner shall pay all civil fines and assessed costs to the finance department within fifteen (15) days of the date of
the written order.
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)
Sec. 20-57. - Issuance of traffic citation.
If payment is not made within thirty (30) days after the notification of the notice of violation, and a timely notice
of appeal has not been filed, then a traffic citation issued under this section shall be issued by mailing the traffic
citation by certified mail to the address of the registered owner of the motor vehicle. Delivery of the citation
constitutes notification. In the case of joint ownership, the traffic citation shall be mailed to the first name
appearing on the registration, unless the first name appearing is a business organization, in which case second
name appearing on the registration may be used. The traffic citation shall be mailed to the registered owner of
the motor vehicle involved in the violation no later than (sixty) 60 days after the date of the violation.
An affidavit supporting any exemption under section 20-56 must include the serial number of the uniform traffic
citation.
The owner of a leased vehicle for which a traffic citation is issued for a violation of these sections when the
driver failed to stop at a traffic signal is not responsible for paying the traffic citation and is not required to
submit an affidavit if the motor vehicle is registered in the name of the lessee of such motor vehicle.
The submission of a false affidavit is a misdemeanor of the second degree, punishable as provided in F.S. §
775.082 or 775.083.
The photographic or electronic images or streaming video attached to or referenced in the traffic citation is
evidence that a violation of F.S. § 316.074(1) or 316.075(1)(c)(1) when the driver failed to stop at a traffic signal
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
591/653
has occurred and is admissible in any proceeding to enforce this section and raises a rebuttable presumption that
the motor vehicle named in the report or shown in the photographic or electronic images or streaming video
evidence was used in violation of [F.S. §] 316.074(1) or 316.075(1)(c)(1) when the driver failed to stop at a
traffic signal.
If a traffic citation is issued under F.S. § 316.0083, the traffic infraction enforcement officer shall provide by
electronic transmission a replica of the traffic citation data to the court having jurisdiction over the alleged
offense or its traffic violations bureau within five (5) days after the date of issuance of the traffic citation to the
violator.
If a person cited for a violation of F.S. § 316.074(1) or 316.075(1)(c)(1), as enforced by a traffic infraction
enforcement officer under [F.S. §] 316.0083, presents documentation from the city that the traffic citation was
issued in error, the clerk of the court may dismiss the case. The clerk of the court shall not charge for this
service.
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)
Sec. 20-58. - Penalties.
A violation of this article is a civil, noncriminal infraction. A civil fine in the amount of one hundred fifty-eight
dollars ($158.00) shall be assessed for each notice of violation, unless the violation is during a courtesy warning
period or is dismissed based upon a valid exemption. These fines shall be distributed in accordance with F.S. §
316.0083(1)(b)(3), as may be amended from time to time, with enforcement by the city. If payment is not made
within thirty (30) days following the date of the notification of the notice of violation, and no timely notice of
appeal has been filed, then the owner is subject to all court fees, costs and the fines associated with the issuance
of a traffic citation.
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)
Sec. 20-59. - Collection of fines.
The city may for the purposes of collecting any delinquent civil fines from the owner, refer the delinquency to a
debt collection agency. The collection fee, including any reasonable attorney's fee, paid to the collection agency
shall be in accordance with Florida law.
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)
Sec. 20-60. - Report.
The city shall submit a report by October 1, 2012, and annually thereafter, to the department of transportation
detailing the results of using the traffic infraction detector and the procedures for enforcement for the preceding
state fiscal year. The information submitted by the city must include statistical data and information required by
the department.
(Ord. No. 10O-09-167, § 1, 10-25-2010)

ARTICLE II. - WATER
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 21-20. - Sprinkling or propelling water onto roadways prohibited; penalty.
(a)
It shall be unlawful for any person to allow a water sprinkling devise or an automatic water sprinkling system to
operate in such a manner that water is sprinkled or propelled onto a roadway causing a safety hazard for
vehicular traffic.
(b)
Failure to correct said problem within ten (10) days after receiving notice of violation of this section shall be
punished by the imposition of a fine, in an amount not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
(Ord. No. 85-179, § 1, 9-9-85; Ord. No. 02O-08-151, § 1, 9-9-02)
Editor's note— Ord. No. 84-144, § 1, adopted July 30, 1984, rescinded former § 21-20. Former § 21-20 was
concerned with the prohibition of connecting lawn sprinkler to the municipal water system and derived from
Ord. No. 80-148, §§ 1, 2, adopted September 29, 1980.
Sec. 21-21. - Plans and permit required; exception.
(a)
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or install any water mains within the city without first submitting
to the city plans and specifications showing the work to be done, materials to be used, and receiving a permit
from the city prior to the commencement of any work in connection with the construction of said water mains.
(b)
This section shall not apply to service to individual houses of water line of one inch or less. The charge for an
engineering permit for water line of more than one inch will be one-half (½) of one (1) percent of the total
contract price.
(Ord. No. 112, §§ 1, 2, 4-14-69; Ord. No. 98O-11-168, § 1, 11-23-98)
Sec. 21-22. - Reserved.
Editor's note— Former § 21-22 pertained to fire hydrant spacing and flow requirements, was repealed by § 1 of
Ord. No. 90-151, adopted Aug. 13, 1990, and derived from Ord. No. 112, adopted Apr. 14, 1969; Ord. No. 80-
165, adopted Nov. 10, 1980; and Ord. No. 85-107, adopted Feb. 11, 1985. For current, similar provisions, see
Schedule I of the city's land development regulations published under separate cover.
Sec. 21-23. - Minimum standards—Established.
There is hereby incorporated by reference and established as minimum standards for the installation and
construction of water mains within the city the engineering standards found at schedule L of the land
development regulations.
(Ord. No. 112, § 3, 4-14-69; Ord. No. 98O-11-168, § 2, 11-23-98)
Sec. 21-24. - Same—Conformity required.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
593/653
All water mains installed within the city shall conform with the minimum standards above set forth.
(Ord. No. 112, § 4, 4-14-69)
Sec. 21-25. - Duty of engineer; issuance of permit; violations.
It shall be the duty of the city engineer to review said plans and specifications so submitted prior to the issuance
of a building permit, and if the plans and specifications meet the minimum requirements set forth in this article,
he shall approve said plans, whereupon the clerk shall issue said permit.
The city engineer shall periodically inspect the construction of the water mains to assure that the water mains are
constructed in accordance with the plans and specifications. In the event that the city engineer's inspection
reveals that the construction is not in accordance with the plans, specifications and requirements of this article,
then the city engineer shall notify the party to whom the permit is issued of such violation, and in the event such
violation is not cured immediately, then he shall order that all work on the water mains to cease until such
arrangements satisfactory to the city are made to correct said violation.
(Ord. No. 112, § 5, 4-14-69)
Sec. 21-26. - Reserved.
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 98O-11-169, adopted November 23, 1998, deleted § 21-26. Formerly,
said section pertained to the permit fee for construction of water mains and derived from Ord. No. 112, § 7,
adopted April 14, 1969. Similar provisions may be located in schedule L of the city land development
regulations.
Sec. 21-27. - Engineer to approve water mains and fire hydrant layout.
Before a building permit may be issued for any construction project involving water mains, approval must be
obtained from the city engineer on the water main layout, including fire hydrant locations.
(Ord. No. 145, § 1, 9-28-70)
Sec. 21-28. - Certification of fire hydrant layout prerequisite to issuance of certificate of occupancy.
No certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any new construction within the city unless the city engineer and
the city building inspector shall certify to the fact that fire hydrants are installed and properly functioning in
accordance with the requirements of this article, as to location and distance from fire hydrants to commercial
and residential buildings and in accordance with the minimum standards for the installation and construction of
water mains within the city as contained in this article.
(Ord. No. 145, § 2, 9-28-70)
Sec. 21-29. - Reserved.
DIVISION 2. - WATER SHORTAGE
Footnotes:
--- (2) ---
Editor's note— Ord. No. 85-159, §§ 1—8, adopted June 24, 1985, has been treated as superseding the provision
of §§ 21-30—21-30.7 were concerned with similar provisions and derived from Ord. No. 81-147, §§ 1—7 and
10, enacted May 18, 1981.
Sec. 21-30. - Intent and purpose.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
594/653
It is the intent and purpose of this division to protect the water resources of the City of Lauderhill from the
harmful effects of overutilization during periods of water shortage and allocate available water supplies by
assisting the South Florida Water Management District in the implementation of its Water Shortage Plan.
(Ord. No. 85-159, § 1, 6-24-85)
Sec. 21-30.1. - Definitions.
For the purpose of this division, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall have the meaning
given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words
in the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural. The word "shall" is always
mandatory and not merely directory.
(1)
District is the South Florida Water Management District.
(2)
Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind.
(3)
Water resource means any and all water on or beneath the surface of the ground, including natural or artificial
water courses, lakes, ponds, or diffused surface water, and water percolating, standing or flowing beneath the
surface of the ground.
(4)
Water shortage condition is when sufficient water is not available to meet the present or anticipated needs of
persons using the water resource, or when conditions are such as to require temporary reduction in total water
usage within a particular area to protect the water resource from serious harm. A water shortage usually occurs
due to drought.
(5)
Water shortage emergency means that situation when the powers which can be exercised under part II of chapter
40E-21, Florida Administrative Code, are not sufficient to protect the public health, safety, or welfare, or the
health of animals, fish or aquatic life, or a public water supply, or commercial, industrial, agricultural,
recreational or other reasonable uses.
(Ord. No. 85-159, § 2, 6-24-85)
Sec. 21-30.2. - Applicability.
The provisions of this division shall apply to all persons using the water resource within the geographical areas
subject to the "water shortage" or "water shortage emergency," as determined by the district, whether from
public or privately owned water utility systems, private wells, or private connections with surface water bodies.
This division shall not apply to persons using treated effluent or saltwater.
(Ord. No. 85-159, § 3, 6-24-85)
Sec. 21-30.3. - Amendments to water shortage plan.
Chapter 40E-21, Florida Administrative Code, as same may be amended from time to time, is incorporated
herein by reference as a part of the Lauderhill City Code.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
595/653
(Ord. No. 85-159, § 4, 6-24-85)
Sec. 21-30.4. - Declaration of water shortage or water shortage emergency.
The declaration of a water shortage or water shortage emergency within all or any part of the City of Lauderhill
by the governing board or the executive director of the district shall invoke the provisions of this division. Upon
such declaration, all water use restrictions or other measures adopted by the district applicable to the City of
Lauderhill or any portion thereof, shall be subject to enforcement action pursuant to this division. Any violation
of the provisions of Chapter 40E-21, Florida Administrative Code, or any order issued pursuant thereto, shall be
a violation of this division.
(Ord. No. 85-159, § 5, 6-24-85)
Sec. 21-30.5. - Enforcement.
Every police officer or sheriff having jurisdiction in the area governed by this division shall, in connection with
all other duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this division. In addition, the county/city
administrator may also delegate enforcement responsibility for this division to agencies and departments of
county/city government, or cities in the service areas governed by this division, in accordance with state and
local law.
(Ord. No. 85-159, § 6, 6-24-85)
Sec. 21-30.6. - Penalties.
Violation of any provision of this division shall be subject to the following penalties:
(1)
First violation: Twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
(2)
Second and subsequent violations: Fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or imprisonment in the
county jail not to exceed sixty (60) days.
Each day in violation of this division shall constitute a separate offense. In the initial stages of a water shortage
or water shortage emergency, law enforcement officials may provide violators with no more than one (1) written
warning. The county/city, in addition to the criminal sanctions contained herein, may take any other appropriate
legal action, including but not limited to emergency injunctive action, to enforce the provisions of this division.
(Ord. No. 85-159, § 7, 6-24-85)
Sec. 21-30.7. - Water users to accept provisions.
No water service shall be furnished to any person by a public or private utility unless such person agrees to
accept all the provisions of this division. The acceptance of water service shall be in itself the acceptance of the
provisions thereof.
(Ord. No. 85-159, § 8, 6-24-85)
ARTICLE III. - SANITARY SEWERS
Sec. 21-31. - Plans and permit required; exception.
(a)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
596/653
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or install any sanitary sewers within the city without first
submitting to the city plans and specifications showing the work to be done, materials to be used and receiving a
permit from the city prior to the commencement of any work in connection with the construction of said sewers.
(b)
This section shall not apply to the installation of sewers to individual buildings having a diameter of six (6)
inches or less.
(Ord. No. 113, § 2, 4-14-69)
Sec. 21-32. - Minimum standards—Established.
There is hereby incorporated by reference and established as minimum standards for the installation and
construction of sewer services within the city the following minimum standards, entitled "Specifications for
Materials and Installation of Sanitary Sewers for the City of Lauderhill, Florida," as prepared by T.G. Lively,
Consulting Engineer, Appendix D to his Code.
(Ord. No. 113, § 3, 4-14-69)
Sec. 21-33. - Same—Conformity required.
All sewers installed within the city shall conform with the minimum standard above set forth.
(Ord. No. 113, § 4, 4-14-69)
Sec. 21-34. - Duty of engineer to review plans; issuance of permit by clerk; periodic inspections by engineer
required; violations.
It shall be the duty of the city engineer to review said plans and specifications so submitted prior to the issuance
of a building permit, and if the plans and specifications meet the minimum requirements set forth in this article,
he shall approve said plans, whereupon the clerk shall issue said permit. The city engineer shall periodically
inspect the construction of the sewers, to assure that the sewers are constructed in accordance with the plans and
specifications. In the event that the city engineer's inspection reveals that the construction is not in accordance
with the plans and specifications and requirements of this article then the city engineer shall notify the party to
whom the permit is issued of such violation and, in the event such violation is not cured immediately, then he
shall order that all work on the sewers cease until such arrangements satisfactory to the city are made to correct
said violation.
(Ord. No. 113, § 5, 4-14-69)
Secs. 21-35, 21-36. - Reserved.
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 98O-11-169, adopted November 23, 1998, deleted §§ 21-35 and 21-36.
Formerly, said sections pertained to the permit fee for construction of sewers and approval of site drainage plans,
respectively, and derived from Ord. No. 113, §§ 6, 7, adopted April 14, 1969. Similar provisions may be located
in schedule L of the city land development regulations.
Sec. 21-37. - Grease traps; inspection and cleaning.
(a)
Inspection required; fee. All grease traps within the city shall be inspected at intervals to be determined by the
chief plumbing inspector to ascertain whether said grease traps are clogged and/or are in need of cleaning,
except that an inspection shall not be required for those grease traps which have been cleaned within the prior
thirty (30) days, with proof of said cleaning being demonstrated as provided herein.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
597/653
(b)
Inspection and cleaning chart. Each establishment in which a grease trap is located shall be given a grease trap
inspection and cleaning chart by the chief plumbing inspector and said chart shall be displayed in a conspicuous
place on the premises. The city chief plumbing inspector, upon completion of an inspection, shall initial the chart
indicating whether the grease trap needs cleaning and/or declogging. Any firm or individual cleaning and/or
declogging the grease traps shall initial the chart indicating the date when said grease trap was cleaned and/or
declogged, the nature of the work and the name of the firm or individual performing the work. Said firm or
individual must have an occupational license that authorizes them to perform this service and any approvals
required by the county health department.
(c)
Cleaning and/or repair required. If the chief plumbing inspector, after an inspection has been made, determines
that a grease trap needs cleaning or repair due to clogging, then, the firm or individual using said grease trap
shall be notified that they have ten (10) days to do the necessary cleaning or repair work that will return said
grease trap to a clean and unclogged condition. If the required cleaning or repair work is not completed within
ten (10) days of said notice, then the firm or individual using said grease trap shall be subject to a penalty as
provided herein. Notice shall be given by the entry made by the chief plumbing inspector on the establishment's
cleaning chart.
(d)
Inspection fee. There shall be charged an inspection fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each grease trap
inspected. The fee shall be charged on September 1 of each year and shall be billed with the occupational license
tax. The fee shall be delinquent if not paid by October 1. Penalties for nonpayment shall be subject to subsection
(e).
(e)
Penalties; delinquent bills. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of up to
one hundred dollars ($100.00) or incarceration for a period up to thirty (30) days, or both. For the purpose of this
section, each day wherein a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed a separate and distinct violation. A
violation occurs when a firm or person using the grease trap in question fails to have the cleaning and/or repair
work for declogging performed within the ten-day time period as provided herein, or fails to pay the required
inspection fee as provided in subsection (d).
(Ord. No. 84-114, §§ 1—4, 5-29-84; Ord. No. 91-171, § 1, 9-11-91; Ord. No. 93-126, § 1, 4-12-93)
Secs. 21-38—21-44. - Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND ENGINEERING SERVICES RULES,
REGULATIONS AND RATES
Footnotes:
--- (3) ---
Editor's note— At the city's request, nonamendatory Ord. No. 87-164, §§ 1 and 2, adopted Jan. 25, 1988, has
been added to the Code and codified as Art. IV, §§ 21-45—21-47, at the editor's discretion.
Charter reference— City council to set by ordinance service or user charges for municipal services, § 4.04(5).
Cross reference— Department of environmental and engineering services, § 2-91 et seq.; references to "utility,"
§ 2-93.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
598/653
Sec. 21-45. - Definitions.
For the purposes of this article, the terms used herein shall be defined as follows:
Consumer: Any person, firm, association, corporation, agency or similar organization supplied with refuse
collection and water and/or sewer service by the department, sometimes referred to as the "customer."
Consumer's installation: All pipes, shutoffs, valves, fixtures and appliances or apparatus of every kind and nature
used in connection with or forming a part of an installation for utilizing water and sewer service for any purpose,
ordinarily located on the consumer's of "point of delivery," whether such installation is owned outright by the
consumer or used by the consumer under lease or otherwise.
Council: The duly elected authority of the city.
Department: The department of environmental and engineering services or its representative of the city, its office
address as currently shown on all department correspondence and customer bills. Hereinafter, sometimes
referred to as the "utility."
In-line valve: The valve located outside the building which controls the flow of water into the building.
Main: Shall refer to a pipe, conduit or other facility installed to convey service to individual lines or other mains.
Point of delivery: The point where the department of environmental and engineering services' pipes or meters
are connected with pipes of the consumer, generally, at the property line, easement line or edge of a right-ofway.
Rate schedule: Refers to the rate or charge for the particular classification of service or services.
Refuse: All waste which is collected pursuant to the city's franchise for refuse collection, removal and disposal
as it now exists, or as it may be amended, extended, renewed or rewarded, and including garbage and trash
receptacles which are required pursuant to section 10-13 of the Code. Required payment for these garbage and
trash receptacles shall be included in refuse collection charges.
Service: As mentioned herein and in agreement with consumers, shall be construed to include, in addition to all
water service or sewer service required by the consumer, the readiness and ability on the part of the department
of environmental and engineering services to furnish such service to the consumer. Thus, the maintenance by the
department of the availability of service at the point of delivery upon request shall constitute the rendering of
service, regardless of whether the consumer makes any use thereof.
Service lines: The pipes of the department of environmental and engineering services which are connected from
the mains to the point of delivery.
(Ord. No. 87-164, §§ 1, 2, 1-25-88; Ord. No. 91-164, § 2, 9-1-91; Ord. No. 94-145, § 1, 9-12-94; Ord. No. 95-
149, § 2, 9-11-95)
Sec. 21-46. - Rules and regulations.
(a)
General information. The department's rules and regulations insofar as they are inconsistent with any statute, law
or legislation now in effect, shall be null and void. These rules and regulations are a part of the rate schedules,
applications and contracts of the department; and, in the absence of a specific written agreement to the contrary,
they apply without modifications or change to each and every consumer to whom the department renders
service.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
599/653
In the event that a portion of these rules and regulations is declared unconstitutional or void for any reason by
any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall in no way affect the validity of the remaining portions of
the rules and regulations for service unless such court order to decision shall so direct.
(b)
Water/sewer service. To obtain service, an application, if required, should be made at the office of the
department. Applications are accepted by the department with the understanding that there is no obligation on
the part of the department to render service other than that which is then available from its existing water
production and distribution equipment and service lines or its sewage treatment or collection system.
The applicant shall furnish to the department the correct name, street address and lot and block number at which
service is to be rendered.
(c)
Signed application necessary. For newly constructed buildings which have not had prior permanent utility
service, service shall be furnished only upon receipt of a signed application or agreement accepted by the
department. The conditions of such application or agreement shall be binding upon the consumer. A copy of
each application or agreement for service accepted by the department will be furnished to the applicant.
(d)
Service supplied only to owners. Utility service shall be provided to property owners, and not to tenants.
Acceptance of utility service by owners or tenants shall constitute an agreement by the owner to pay for the
service.
(e)
Withholding service. The department may withhold or discontinue service when the account becomes delinquent
as provided for herein or when an acceptable application is not provided.
(f)
Extensions. Water or sewer main extensions required shall be the responsibility of the developer/builder for
design and installation subject to approval by the city engineer. The department may require from the
developer/builder prepayments, cash advances, minimum guarantees, contribution in aid of construction or other
arrangements with the developer/builder whereby the department will be enabled to earn a fair and reasonable
return on the cost of providing and rendering the required service.
(g)
Limitation of use. All service purchased from the department shall be used by the consumer only for the
purposes specified by the department, and the consumer shall not sell or otherwise dispose of such service
supplied by the department. Service furnished to the consumer shall be rendered directly to the consumer
through the department's individual meter or connection and shall be for consumer's own use and may not be
remetered by the consumer for the purpose of selling or otherwise disposing of service to lessees, tenants or
others and under no circumstances shall the consumer or consumer's agent or any other individual association or
corporation install meters or pipes for the purpose of so remetering said service, except for the purpose of the
allocation of the direct cost of water and sewer service among multiple users, and then only pursuant to the city's
express approval and only to the extent thereof. Subject to the consent of the city commission and pursuant to
the terms of limitation of the applicable remetering agreement, a consumer may remeter the water service
provided by the city solely for the purposes of determining the use thereof among the consumer's lessees, tenants
or others who shall be lawfully entitled to receive same. Any owner or remeterer who has installed submeters
and who has been individually billing residents for water service prior to the adoption of this section shall have
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
600/653
ninety (90) days from the date of enactment to comply with the provisions of this section. In no case shall a
consumer, except with the written consent of the department, extend his lines across a street, alley, lane, court,
property line, avenue or other way, in order to furnish service for adjacent property. If such adjacent extension,
remetering, sale or disposition of service should occur, the consumer's service is subject to discontinuance until
such unauthorized extension, remetering, sale or disposition is discontinued and full payment is made of bills for
service calculated on proper classification and rate schedules and reimbursement in full made to the department
for all extra expenses incurred for clerical work, testing and inspections.
(h)
Continuity of service. The utility will at all times use reasonable diligence to provide continuous service and,
having used reasonable diligence, shall not be liable to the consumer for failure or interruption of continuous
service. The utility shall not be liable for any act or omission caused directly or indirectly by strikes, labor
troubles, accident, litigations, breakdowns, shutdowns for repairs or adjustments, acts of sabotage, enemies of
the United States, state, municipal or other governmental interference, acts of God or other causes beyond its
control.
(i)
Type and maintenance. The consumer's pipes, apparatus and equipment shall be selected, installed, used and
maintained in accordance with the standard practice, conforming with the rules and regulations of the
department and in full compliance with all laws and governmental regulations applicable to same. The consumer
agrees, further, to keep all pipes, valves and plumbing fixtures in repair and to promptly stop all leaks on his
premises; and the department shall not be responsible for their maintenance and operation. The consumer shall
not utilize any applicant or device which may adversely affect the service and the department reserves the right
to discontinue or withhold service to such apparatus or device.
(j)
Change of consumer's installation. No changes or increases in the consumer's installation which will materially
affect the proper operation of the pipes, mains or stations of the department shall be made without written
consent of the department. The consumer will be liable for any change resulting from a violation of this rule.
(k)
Inspection of consumer's installation. All of the consumer's service installations or changes shall be inspected
upon completion by competent authority to ensure that the consumer's piping, equipment and devices have been
installed in accordance with accepted standard practice and such local governmental or other rules as may be in
effect.
Where municipal or other governmental inspection is required by local rules or ordinances, the department
cannot render service until such inspection has been made, and a formal notice of approval from the inspecting
authority has been received by the department.
The department reserves the right to inspect the consumer's installation prior to rendering service and from time
to time thereafter, but assumes no responsibility whatsoever for any portion thereof.
(l)
Protection of utility's property. The consumer shall properly protect the utility's property on the consumer's
premises and shall permit no one but the utility's agents or persons authorized by law to have access to the
utility's pipes and apparatus.
In the event of any loss or damage to property of the utility caused by or arising out of carelessness, neglect or
other misuse by the consumer, the cost of making good such loss or repairing such damage shall be paid by the
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
601/653
consumer.
(m)
Access to premises. The duly authorized agents of the department shall have access at all reasonable hours to the
premises of the consumer for the purpose of installing, maintaining and inspecting or removing the department's
property, reading meters and other purposes incident to the provision of, or termination of, service to the
consumer and, in such performance shall not be liable for trespass.
(n)
Right-of-way easements. The builder/developer or consumer shall grant or cause to be granted to the department
and without cost to the department all rights, easements, permits and privileges which, in the department's
opinion, are necessary for the rendering of service.
(o)
Billing period. Bills for water and sewer service will be rendered every month each bill to charge for the actual
usage for the prior month with the new billing period to begin effective October 1, 2006. Bills are due when
rendered and shall be considered as received by the consumer when mailed to the service address or some other
place mutually agreed upon.
(p)
Delinquent bills. Bills are due when rendered and, if not paid within twenty-five (25) days thereafter, become
delinquent, are subject to a one (1) percent penalty per billing cycle on the unpaid balance. The finance director
shall have the authority to waive a penalty fee at the customer's request if the customer has not been delinquent
in payments for the prior twelve (12) months; and service may then be discontinued after the due date. Notice
that service will be discontinued if the bill is not paid within twenty-five (25) days shall appear on the face of the
original bill. If a customer who is on the turn off list can prove at the time of turn off that payment has been
made in full, then the utility service will not be discontinued and a fee of only twenty-five dollars ($25.00) will
be assessed. If a service is discontinued, a disconnect fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) if made during normal working
hours, and seventy-five dollars ($75.00) if made during other than normal working hours, shall be added to the
outstanding balance due from the customer. A reading of the meter shall be taken when turned off and recorded.
Service will be resumed only upon payment of the total amount due, including penalties, unless a payment
arrangement is approved by the finance director. There shall be no liability of any kind against the city by reason
of discontinuance of service to the customer for failure of the customer to pay bills when due. Any fee which is
charged to the customer pursuant to section 21-46, shall constitute a delinquent payment. A partial payment, if
accepted, shall not be a waiver of the remaining balance due from the customer.
(q)
Reserved.
(r)
Reimbursement for extra expenses. The consumer shall reimburse the department for all extra expenses (such as
for special trips, inspections, additional clerical expenses, etc.) incurred by the department on account of the
consumer's violation of the contract for service or of the department's rules and regulations.
(s)
Payment of water, sewer and refuse service bills concurrently.
(1)
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
602/653
When a consumer is billed for refuse, water and sewer service, this subsection shall apply. Refuse collection,
water service and sewer service shall be billed concurrently, with refuse collection being billed at the time
prescribed in these rules and regulations [section 21-46] for billing of water and sewer service. If a customer
shall pay less than the entire bill, the payment shall be applied first to refuse collection, then to sewer service and
finally to water service. If the department shall discontinue water service due to nonpayment for the service, it
shall also discontinue sewer service. The department shall not reestablish or reconnect water and sewer service
until such time as all refuse collection charges, sewer service charges, water service charges and all other fees
and charges established by these rules and regulations are fully paid.
(2)
When a consumer is billed only for water and sewer service, this subsection shall apply. When both water and
sewer service are provided for by the department, payment of any water service bill rendered by the department
to a water service consumer shall not be accepted by the department without the simultaneous or concurrent
payment of any sewer service bill rendered by the department. If the charges for water service are not so paid,
the department may discontinue both sewer service and water services to the consumer's premises for
nonpayment of the water service charges or, if the charges for sewer service are not so paid, the department may
discontinue both water and sewer service to the consumer's premises for nonpayment of the sewer service
charge. The department shall not reestablish or reconnect sewer service and water service or either of such
services until such time as all sewer service charges and water service charges and all other expenses or charges
established or provided for by these rules and regulations [section 21-46] are paid.
(t)
Change of ownership. When a change of ownership of a property supplied with water and sewer service shall
occur, it shall be the obligation of the parties to the transaction to determine each party's obligation for its portion
of fees and costs incurred by this section. If requested, the city will supply a meter reading, in conjunction with a
lien search. There shall be an additional fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the meter reading.
(u)
Unauthorized water connections. Connections to the department's water system for any purpose whatsoever are
to be made only by employees of the department. Unauthorized connections render the service subject to
immediate discontinuance without notice, and service will not be restored until such unauthorized connections
have been removed and unless settlement is made in full for all service estimated by the department to have been
used by reason of such unauthorized connection.
Any unauthorized connection or any consumer who tampers with a meter sealed by the department shall be
subject to a minimum charge of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) or actual cost incurred, whichever is larger,
to cover the cost of investigation, legal action, repairs or further protection of the department's product or
property. If the reading on a meter that is disconnected by the city is higher at the next reading than what the city
recorded as the reading at the time the meter was disconnected by the city, then the customer will be charged a
tampering fee and the meter will be removed until such time as all payments are made and the city reconnects
such service. Any illegal connection such as "jumper", tampering with service-locking device, bypassing of
meter or stolen meter shall be subject to a minimum charge of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or the actual costs
incurred, whichever is larger, to cover the cost of investigation, legal action, repairs or further protection of the
department's product or property. The meter will only be replaced after all outstanding balances and fees are
paid.
(v)
Meters. All water meters shall be furnished by and remain the property of the department and shall be accessible
to and subject to its control. The consumer shall provide meter space to the department at a suitable and readily
accessible location and, when the department considers it advisable within the premises to be served, adequate
and proper space for the installation of meters and other similar devices.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
603/653
(w)
All water through meter. That portion of the consumer's installation for water service shall be so arranged that all
water service shall pass through the meter. No temporary pipes, nipples, cross connections, or spacers are
permitted and under no circumstances are connections allowed which may permit water to bypass the meter or
metering equipment.
(x)
Adjustment of bills. When a consumer has been overcharged or undercharged as a result of incorrect application
of the rate schedules, incorrect reading of the meter, incorrect connection of the meter or other similar reasons,
the amount may be credited or billed to the consumer, as the case may be.
(y)
Deposit. A deposit shall be required for all two-inch meters and all meters not affixed to a permanent structure or
address. The amount of the deposit shall be as set forth in section 21-47.
(z)
Request for meter test by consumer. Should any consumer request a bench test of their water meter, the
department will require a fee to defray the cost of testing; such fee is not to exceed the following schedule of
fees:

If a meter is found to register in excess of the prescribed accuracy limits, the fee will be refunded; but if it is
below such accuracy limit, the fee will be retained by the department as a service charge for conducting the test.
(aa)
Adjustment of bills for meter error. The accuracy of the registration of the meter and its performance in service
shall be judged by its average error. The average meter error shall be considered to be the average of the errors at
the test-rate flows.
Fast meters: Whenever a meter tested is found to register fast in excess of the tolerance provided in the meter
accuracy requirements provision herein, the utility shall issue a credit to the consumer for the amount billed in
error for one-half (½) the period since the last test, said one-half (½) period not to exceed six (6) months; except
that if it can be shown that the error was due to some cause, the date of which can be fixed, the overcharge shall
be computed back to but not beyond such date. The credit shall not include any part of any minimum charge.
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
604/653
Slow meters. Whenever a meter tested is found to register slow in excess of the tolerance provided in the meter
accuracy requirements provision herein, the utility may bill the consumer an amount equal to the unbilled error
for one-half (½) the period since the last test, said one-half (½) period not to exceed six (6) months; except that
if it can be shown that the error was due to some cause, the date of which can be fixed, the charge may be
computed back to but not beyond such date; and provided, further, that if the utility has required a deposit, the
consumer may be billed only for that portion of the unbilled error.
In the event of a nonregister meter, the consumer may be billed on an estimate based on previous bills for similar
usage, such estimate to apply only to the current billing period.
In the event of unauthorized use, the consumer may be billed on a reasonable estimate of the service taken.
Meter accuracy requirements. All meters used for measuring the quantity of water delivered to a consumer shall
be in good mechanical condition and shall be adequate in size and design for the type of service which they
measure. Before being installed for the use of any consumer, every water meter, whether new, repaired or
removed from service for any cause, shall be adjusted to register within the accuracy limits set forth in the
following table with accuracy limits in percent:
MAXIMUM INTERMEDIATE

(bb)
Failure of water service due to in-line valve shutoff. When city personnel are dispatched to a consumer's address
to turn on water service, and water is not being supplied to the consumer because the in-line valve is shut off, the
consumer shall be charged a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) if the consumer's request is received between 8:00
a.m. and 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday. If the consumer's request is received at other hours or on Saturday,
Sunday, or a legal holiday, the consumer shall be billed a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00).
(cc)
Sewer stoppage on a consumer's property. When city personnel are utilized to clear a sewer stoppage which
occurs on the consumer's property inside the point of delivery, the consumer shall be charged a fee of fifty
dollars ($50.00) if the consumer's request is received between 8:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday,
and one hundred dollars ($100.00) if the consumer's request is received at other hours or on Saturday or Sunday,
or a legal holiday.
(dd)
Refuse service and billing. All services and charges relating to refuse collection shall be as set forth in the city's
franchise for refuse collection, removal and disposal services. Billing for refuse collection service shall be by the
11/8/2019 Lauderhill, FL Code of Ordinances
605/653
city, to the extent that it is required in the franchise for refuse collection, removal and disposal. All such billing
shall be pursuant to the terms of subsection(s).
(ee)
System price structure. Commencing December 1, 2007, and effective on the 1st of October of each year
thereafter, all water, sewer and stormwater availability charges (minimum service charge), service and
consumption rate charges then in effect will be adjusted automatically in an amount up to one hundred (100)
percent of the U.S. Department of Labor Consumer Price Index ("CPI") as determined in June of the calendar
year of adjustment to be necessary to cover the expenses to the city. If the CPI for any year is below zero, the
city would not be obligated to increase the rate charges for that year.
(ff)
[Owners of private lift stations.] Owners of private lift stations located within the City of Lauderhill shall be
required to:
(1)
Display emergency contact information on the station at all times. A failure to comply with this subsection shall
be subject to the issuance for such violation.
(2)
Provide maintenance records for the privately owned lift station when requested by the city.
(3)
If at any time the owner does not maintain the private lift station and the city determines that it has become a
public health and safety issue, then the city shall be entitled to conduct any necessary repairs to the station and
the owner shall immediately reimburse the city for any and all costs incurred to the city as a result of that repair.
If owner fails to reimburse the city within thirty (30) days, the city shall be entitled to place a lien on the real
property on which the lift station is located, which lien shall be payable with interest at the then current legal rate
of interest per annum and which lien shall be deemed to be a special assessment lien, equal in dignity to city and
county ad valorem taxes and superior in rank and dignity to all other liens, encumbrances, titles and claims in or
to the real property. The payment of all costs of collection, including reasonable attorney's fees, penalties and
lien amounts shall be required before said lien shall be discharged or satisfied.
